"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNN", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "CNN"}}], "eventDate": "2024-08-06", "totalArticleCount": 132, "title": {"eng": "We're about to get the most detailed flight.\n\nThe public already knows a lot about the January 5 Alaska Airlines flight that had a door plug blow out of the side of a Boeing 737 Max as it approached 16,000 feet. {"uri": "2024-08-445214756", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "04:30:48", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T04:30:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T04:01:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9254902005195618, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/witnesses-will-tell-a-federal-safety-board-about-the-blowout-on-a-boeing-737-max/article_34834293-5b30-5ce1-81f4-cd383ac8bd99.html", "title": "Witnesses will tell a federal safety board about the blowout on a Boeing 737 Max earlier this year", "body": "FILE - The door plug from the Alaska Airlines Flight 1282's Boeing 737-9 MAX airplane is shown at the National Transportation Safety Board laboratory, in Washington, July 30, 2024. On Tuesday, August 6, 2024, the National Transportation Safety Board opens a two-day hearing on the blowout of the door plug from the Alaska Airlines flight traveling 16,000 feet above Oregon.\n\nInvestigators will question Boeing officials during a hearing starting Tuesday about the midflight blowout of a panel from a 737 Max, an accident that further tarnished the company's safety reputation and left it facing new legal jeopardy.\n\nThe two-day hearing could provide new insight into the Jan. 5 accident, which caused a loud boom and left a gaping hole in the side of the Alaska Airlines jet.\n\nThe National Transportation Safety Board has said in a preliminary report that four bolts that help secure the panel, which is call a door plug, were not replaced after a repair job in a Boeing factory, but the company has said the work was not documented. During the two-day hearing, safety board members are expected to question Boeing officials about the lack of paperwork that might have explained how such a potentially tragic mistake occurred.\n\n\"The NTSB wants to fill in the gaps of what is known about this incident and to put people on the record about it,\" said John Goglia, a former NTSB member. The agency will be looking to underscore Boeing's failures in following the process it had told the Federal Aviation Administration it was going to use in such cases, he said.\n\nThe safety board will not determine a probable cause after the hearing. That could take another year or longer. It is calling the unusually long hearing a fact-finding step.\n\nAmong the scheduled witnesses is Elizabeth Lund, who has been Boeing's senior vice president of quality -- a new position -- since February, and officials from Spirit AeroSystems, which makes fuselages for Max jets.\n\nSpirit installed the door plug -- a panel that fills a space created for an extra exit on some planes -- on the Alaska Airlines jet, but the panel was removed and the bolts taken off in a Boeing factory near Seattle to repair rivets.\n\nThe NTSB's agenda for the hearing includes testimony about manufacturing and inspections, the opening and closing of the door plug in the Boeing factory, safety systems at Boeing and Spirit, and the FAA's supervision of Boeing.\n\nFAA Administrator Mike Whitaker has conceded that his agency's oversight of the company \"was too hands-off -- too focused on paperwork audits and not focused enough on inspections.\" He has said that is changing.\n\nThe plane involved had been delivered to Alaska Airlines in late October and had made only about 150 flights. The airline stopped using the plane on flights to Hawaii after a warning light indicating a possible pressurization problem lit up on three different flights.\n\nThe accident on flight 1282 occurred minutes after takeoff from Portland, Oregon, as the plane flew at 16,000 feet (4,800 meters). Oxygen masks dropped during the rapid decompression, a few cell phones and other objects were swept through the hole in the plane, passengers were terrified by wind and roaring noise, but miraculously no one was injured.\n\nThe pilots landed safely back in Portland. The door plug was found in a high school science teacher's backyard in Cedar Hills, Oregon.\n\nNo one from the airline was called to testify this week before the NTSB. Goglia, the former safety board member, said that indicates the agency has determined \"that Alaska has no dirty hands in this.\"\n\nTension remains high between the NTSB and Boeing, however. Two months after the accident, board Chair Jennifer Homendy and Boeing got into a public argument over whether the company was cooperating with investigators.\n\nThat spat was largely smoothed over, but in June a Boeing executive angered the board by discussing the investigation with reporters and -- even worse in the agency's view -- suggesting that the NTSB was interested in finding someone to blame for the blowout.\n\nNTSB officials see their role as identifying the cause of accidents to prevent similar ones in the future. They are not prosecutors, and they fear that witnesses won't come forward if they think NTSB is looking for culprits.\n\nSo the NTSB issued a subpoena for Boeing representatives while stripping the company of its customary right to ask questions during the hearing.\n\nThe accident led to several investigations of Boeing, most of which are still underway.\n\nThe FBI has told passengers on the Alaska Airlines flight that they might be victims of a crime. The Justice Department pushed Boeing to plead guilty to a charge of conspiracy to commit fraud after finding that it failed to live up to a previous settlement related to regulatory approval of the Max.\n\nBoeing, which has yet to recover financially from two deadly crashes of Max jets in 2018 and 2019, has lost more than $25 billion since the start of 2019. Later this week, the company will get its third chief executive in 4 1/2 years.\n\nTestimony from NTSB hearings is not admissible in court, but lawyers suing Boeing over this and other accidents will be watching, knowing that they can seek depositions from witnesses to cover the same ground.\n\n\"Our cases are already solid -- door plugs shouldn't blow out during a flight,\" said one of those lawyers, Mark Lindquist of Seattle. \"Our cases grow even stronger, however, if the blowout was the result of habitually shoddy practices. Are jurors going to see this as negligence or something worse?\"", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Beckley Register-Herald"}, "authors": [{"uri": "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9793139", "eventUri": "eng-9793139", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "-01-05", "textStart": 671, "textEnd": 677}], "sentiment": {"uri": "2024-08-445818680", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "14:16:09", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T14:16:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T13:49:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9254902005195618, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/witnesses-tell-a-federal-safety-board-about-the-blowout-on-a-boeing-737-max-earlier/article_34834293-5b30-5ce1-81f4-cd383ac8bd99.html", "title": "Witnesses tell a federal safety board about the blowout on a Boeing 737 Max earlier this year", "body": "FILE - The door plug from the Alaska Airlines Flight 1282's Boeing 737-9 MAX airplane is shown at the National Transportation Safety Board laboratory, in Washington, July 30, 2024. On Tuesday, August 6, 2024, the National Transportation Safety Board opens a two-day hearing on the blowout of the door plug from the Alaska Airlines flight traveling 16,000 feet above Oregon.\n\nInvestigators are questioning Boeing officials in hearings this week about the midflight blowout of a panel from a 737 Max, an accident that further tarnished the company's safety reputation and left it facing new legal jeopardy.\n\nThe National Transportation Safety Board's two-day hearing, which began Tuesday morning, could provide new insight into the Jan. 5 accident that caused a loud boom and left a gaping hole in the side of the Alaska Airlines jet.\n\n\"This was quite traumatic to the crew and passengers,\" NTSB Chair Jennifer Homendy said as the hearing began Tuesday, speaking to anyone who may have been on the flight or knew someone aboard. \"We are so sorry for all that you experienced during this very traumatic event.\"\n\nThe NTSB said in a preliminary report that four bolts that help secure the panel, which is call a door plug, were not replaced after a repair job in a Boeing factory, but the company has said the work was not documented. During the hearing, safety board members are expected to question Boeing officials about the lack of paperwork that might have explained how such a potentially tragic mistake occurred.\n\n\"The NTSB wants to fill in the gaps of what is known about this incident and to put people on the record about it,\" said John Goglia, a former NTSB member. The agency will be looking to underscore Boeing's failures in following the process it had told the Federal Aviation Administration it was going to use in such cases, he said.\n\nThe safety board will not determine a probable cause after the hearing. That could take another year or longer. It is calling the unusually long hearing a fact-finding step.\n\nAmong the scheduled witnesses is Elizabeth Lund, who has been Boeing's senior vice president of quality -- a new position -- since February, and officials from Spirit AeroSystems, which makes fuselages for Max jets.\n\nSpirit installed the door plug -- a panel that fills a space created for an extra exit on some planes -- on the Alaska Airlines jet, but the panel was removed and the bolts taken off in a Boeing factory near Seattle to repair rivets.\n\nThe NTSB's agenda for the hearing includes testimony about manufacturing and inspections, the opening and closing of the door plug in the Boeing factory, safety systems at Boeing and Spirit, and the FAA's supervision of Boeing.\n\nFAA Administrator Mike Whitaker has conceded that his agency's oversight of the company \"was too hands-off -- too focused on paperwork audits and not focused enough on inspections.\" He has said that is changing.\n\nThe plane involved had been delivered to Alaska Airlines in late October and had made only about 150 flights. The airline stopped using the plane on flights to Hawaii after a warning light indicating a possible pressurization problem lit up on three different flights.\n\nThe accident on flight 1282 occurred minutes after takeoff from Portland, Oregon, as the plane flew at 16,000 feet (4,800 meters). Oxygen masks dropped during the rapid decompression, a few cell phones and other objects were swept through the hole in the plane, passengers were terrified by wind and roaring noise, but miraculously there were no major injuries. Homendy said Tuesday that seven passengers and one flight attendant received minor physical injuries.\n\nThe pilots landed safely back in Portland. The door plug was found in a high school science teacher's backyard in Cedar Hills, Oregon.\n\nNo one from the airline was called to testify this week before the NTSB. Goglia, the former safety board member, said that indicates the agency has determined \"that Alaska has no dirty hands in this.\"\n\nTension remains high between the NTSB and Boeing, however. Two months after the accident, board Chair Jennifer Homendy and Boeing got into a public argument over whether the company was cooperating with investigators.\n\nThat spat was largely smoothed over, but in June a Boeing executive angered the board by discussing the investigation with reporters and -- even worse in the agency's view -- suggesting that the NTSB was interested in finding someone to blame for the blowout.\n\nNTSB officials see their role as identifying the cause of accidents to prevent similar ones in the future. They are not prosecutors, and they fear that witnesses won't come forward if they think NTSB is looking for culprits.\n\nSo the NTSB issued a subpoena for Boeing representatives while stripping the company of its customary right to ask questions during the hearing.\n\nThe accident led to several investigations of Boeing, most of which are still underway.\n\nThe FBI has told passengers on the Alaska Airlines flight that they might be victims of a crime. The Justice Department pushed Boeing to plead guilty to a charge of conspiracy to commit fraud after finding that it failed to live up to a previous settlement related to regulatory approval of the Max.\n\nBoeing, which has yet to recover financially from two deadly crashes of Max jets in 2018 and 2019, has lost more than $25 billion since the start of 2019. Later this week, the company will get its third chief executive in 4 1/2 years.\n\nTestimony from NTSB hearings is not admissible in court, but lawyers suing Boeing over this and other accidents will be watching, knowing that they can seek depositions from witnesses to cover the same ground.\n\n\"Our cases are already solid -- door plugs shouldn't blow out during a flight,\" said one of those lawyers, Mark Lindquist of Seattle. \"Our cases grow even stronger, however, if the blowout was the result of habitually shoddy practices. Are jurors going to see this as negligence or something worse?\"", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Beckley Register-Herald"}, "authors": [{"uri": "wyatte_grantham_philips@register-herald.com", "name": "Wyatte Grantham-Philips", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "david_koenig@register-herald.com", "name": "David Koenig", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alaska_Airlines", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Alaska Airlines"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_737_MAX", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Boeing 737 MAX"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Boeing"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Transportation_Safety_Board", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "National Transportation Safety Board"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_Everett_Factory", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Boeing Everett Factory"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jet_aircraft", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Jet aircraft"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Aviation_Administration", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Federal Aviation Administration"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jennifer_Homendy", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Jennifer Homendy"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flight_International", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Flight International"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airplane", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Airplane"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_(state)", "type": "loc", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Washington (state)"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Washington (state)"}, "country": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_United_States", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Vice President of the United States"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Audit", "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airline", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Airline"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hawaii", "type": "loc", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Hawaii"}, "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9793139", "eventUri": "eng-9793139", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "-01-05", "textStart": 730, "textEnd": 736}], "sentiment": 0.0117647058823529, "wgt": 236, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-08-445909724", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "15:40:04", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T15:40:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T15:08:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9215686321258545, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/witnesses-before-federal-safety-board-testifies-about-blowout-on-a-boeing-737-max-earlier-this/article_34834293-5b30-5ce1-81f4-cd383ac8bd99.html", "title": "Witnesses before federal safety board testifies about blowout on a Boeing 737 Max earlier this year", "body": "FILE - The door plug from the Alaska Airlines Flight 1282's Boeing 737-9 MAX airplane is shown at the National Transportation Safety Board laboratory, in Washington, July 30, 2024. On Tuesday, August 6, 2024, the National Transportation Safety Board opens a two-day hearing on the blowout of the door plug from the Alaska Airlines flight traveling 16,000 feet above Oregon.\n\nInvestigators are questioning Boeing officials in hearings this week about the midflight blowout of a panel from a 737 Max, an accident that further tarnished the company's safety reputation and left it facing new legal jeopardy.\n\nThe National Transportation Safety Board's two-day hearing, which began Tuesday morning, could provide new insight into the Jan. 5 accident that caused a loud boom and left a gaping hole in the side of the Alaska Airlines jet.\n\n\"This was quite traumatic to the crew and passengers,\" NTSB Chair Jennifer Homendy said as the hearing began Tuesday, speaking to anyone who may have been on the flight or knew someone aboard. \"We are so sorry for all that you experienced during this very traumatic event.\"\n\nThe NTSB said in a preliminary report that four bolts that help secure the panel, which is call a door plug, were not replaced after a repair job in a Boeing factory, but the company has said the work was not documented. During the hearing, safety board members are expected to question Boeing officials about the lack of paperwork that might have explained how such a potentially tragic mistake occurred.\n\n\"The NTSB wants to fill in the gaps of what is known about this incident and to put people on the record about it,\" said John Goglia, a former NTSB member. The agency will be looking to underscore Boeing's failures in following the process it had told the Federal Aviation Administration it was going to use in such cases, he said.\n\nThe safety board will not determine a probable cause after the hearing. That could take another year or longer. It is calling the unusually long hearing a \"fact-finding\" step.\n\nThe first witnesses called Tuesday included Elizabeth Lund, Boeing's senior vice president of quality -- a new position -- since February.\n\nBoeing supplier Spirit AeroSystems installed the door plug, a panel on many 737s that fills a cutout left for an extra exit required on some planes. The plug on the Alaska Airlines jet was removed and the bolts taken off in a Boeing factory to repair rivets.\n\nWitnesses for Spirit and Boeing testified about safety systems and inspection processes. Lund said production of Max jets dropped below 10 per month after the Alaska Airlines blowout and has increased. but remains under 30 per month.\n\nLater Tuesday, witnesses are expected to testify about the opening and closing of the door plug and the FAA's oversight of Boeing.\n\nFAA Administrator Mike Whitaker has conceded that his agency's oversight of the company \"was too hands-off -- too focused on paperwork audits and not focused enough on inspections.\" He has said that is changing.\n\nThe plane involved had been delivered to Alaska Airlines in late October and had made only about 150 flights. The airline stopped using the plane on flights to Hawaii after a warning light indicating a possible pressurization problem lit up on three different flights.\n\nThe accident on flight 1282 occurred minutes after takeoff from Portland, Oregon, as the plane flew at 16,000 feet (4,800 meters). Oxygen masks dropped during the rapid decompression, a few cell phones and other objects were swept through the hole in the plane, passengers were terrified by wind and roaring noise, but miraculously there were no major injuries. Homendy said Tuesday that seven passengers and one flight attendant received minor physical injuries.\n\nThe pilots landed safely back in Portland. The door plug was found in a high school science teacher's backyard in Cedar Hills, Oregon.\n\nNo one from the airline was called to testify this week before the NTSB. Goglia, the former safety board member, said that indicates the agency has determined \"that Alaska has no dirty hands in this.\"\n\nTension remains high between the NTSB and Boeing, however. Two months after the accident, board Chair Jennifer Homendy and Boeing got into a public argument over whether the company was cooperating with investigators.\n\nThat spat was largely smoothed over, but in June a Boeing executive angered the board by discussing the investigation with reporters and -- even worse in the agency's view -- suggesting that the NTSB was interested in finding someone to blame for the blowout.\n\nNTSB officials see their role as identifying the cause of accidents to prevent similar ones in the future. They are not prosecutors, and they fear that witnesses won't come forward if they think NTSB is looking for culprits.\n\nSo the NTSB issued a subpoena for Boeing representatives while stripping the company of its customary right to ask questions during the hearing.\n\nThe accident led to several investigations of Boeing, most of which are still underway.\n\nThe FBI has told passengers on the Alaska Airlines flight that they might be victims of a crime. The Justice Department pushed Boeing to plead guilty to a charge of conspiracy to commit fraud after finding that it failed to live up to a previous settlement related to regulatory approval of the Max.\n\nBoeing, which has yet to recover financially from two deadly crashes of Max jets in 2018 and 2019, has lost more than $25 billion since the start of 2019. Later this week, the company will get its third chief executive in 4 1/2 years.\n\nTestimony from NTSB hearings is not admissible in court, but lawyers suing Boeing over this and other accidents will be watching, knowing that they can seek depositions from witnesses to cover the same ground.\n\n\"Our cases are already solid -- door plugs shouldn't blow out during a flight,\" said one of those lawyers, Mark Lindquist of Seattle. \"Our cases grow even stronger, however, if the blowout was the result of habitually shoddy practices. Are jurors going to see this as negligence or something worse?\"", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Beckley Register-Herald"}, "authors": [{"uri": During the hearing, safety board members are expected to question Boeing officials about the lack of paperwork that might have explained how such a potentially tragic mistake occurred.\n\n\"The NTSB wants to fill in the gaps of what is known about this incident and to put people on the record about it,\" said John Goglia, a former NTSB member. The agency will be looking to underscore Boeing's failures in following the process it had told the Federal Aviation Administration it was going to use in such cases, he said.\n\nThe safety board will not determine a probable cause after the hearing. That could take another year or longer. It is calling the unusually long hearing a \"fact-finding\" step.\n\nThe first witnesses called Tuesday included Elizabeth Lund, Boeing's senior vice president of quality -- a new position -- since February.\n\nBoeing supplier Spirit AeroSystems installed the door plug, a panel on many 737s that fills a cutout left for an extra exit required on some planes. The plug on the Alaska Airlines jet was removed and the bolts taken off in a Boeing factory to repair rivets.\n\nWitnesses for Spirit and Boeing testified about safety systems and inspection processes. Lund said production of Max jets dropped below 10 per month after the Alaska Airlines blowout and has increased, but remains under 30 per month.\n\nLater Tuesday, witnesses are expected to testify about the opening and closing of the door plug and the FAA's oversight of Boeing.\n\nFAA Administrator Mike Whitaker has conceded that his agency's oversight of the company \"was too hands-off -- too focused on paperwork audits and not focused enough on inspections.\" He has said that is changing.\n\nThe plane involved had been delivered to Alaska Airlines in late October and had made only about 150 flights. The airline stopped using the plane on flights to Hawaii after a warning light indicating a possible pressurization problem lit up on three different flights.\n\nThe accident on flight 1282 occurred minutes after takeoff from Portland, Oregon, as the plane flew at 16,000 feet (4,800 metres). Oxygen masks dropped during the rapid decompression, a few cell phones and other objects were swept through the hole in the plane, passengers were terrified by wind and roaring noise, but miraculously there were no major injuries. Homendy said Tuesday that seven passengers and one flight attendant received minor physical injuries.\n\nThe pilots landed safely back in Portland. The door plug was found in a high school science teacher's backyard in Cedar Hills, Ore.\n\nThe door plug from the Alaska Airlines Flight 1282's Boeing 737-9 MAX airplane is shown at the National Transportation Safety Board laboratory, in Washington, July 30, 2024. (AP Photo/Manuel Balce Ceneta, File)\n\nNo one from the airline was called to testify this week before the NTSB. Goglia, the former safety board member, said that indicates the agency has determined \"that Alaska has no dirty hands in this.\"\n\nTension remains high between the NTSB and Boeing, however. Two months after the accident, board Chair Jennifer Homendy and Boeing got into a public argument over whether the company was cooperating with investigators.\n\nThat spat was largely smoothed over, but in June a Boeing executive angered the board by discussing the investigation with reporters and -- even worse in the agency's view -- suggesting that the NTSB was interested in finding someone to blame for the blowout.\n\nNTSB officials see their role as identifying the cause of accidents to prevent similar ones in the future. They are not prosecutors, and they fear that witnesses won't come forward if they think NTSB is looking for culprits.\n\nSo the NTSB issued a subpoena for Boeing representatives while stripping the company of its customary right to ask questions during the hearing.\n\nThe accident led to several investigations of Boeing, most of which are still underway.\n\nThe FBI has told passengers on the Alaska Airlines flight that they might be victims of a crime. The Justice Department pushed Boeing to plead guilty to a charge of conspiracy to commit fraud after finding that it failed to live up to a previous settlement related to regulatory approval of the Max.\n\nBoeing, which has yet to recover financially from two deadly crashes of Max jets in 2018 and 2019, has lost more than US$25 billion since the start of 2019. Later this week, the company will get its third chief executive in four-and-a-half years.\n\nTestimony from NTSB hearings is not admissible in court, but lawyers suing Boeing over this and other accidents will be watching, knowing that they can seek depositions from witnesses to cover the same ground.\n\n\"Our cases are already solid -- door plugs shouldn't blow out during a flight,\" said one of those lawyers, Mark Lindquist of Seattle. \"Our cases grow even stronger, however, if the blowout was the result of habitually shoddy practices. "https://www.ctvnews.ca/content/dam/ctvnews/en/images/2024/8/6/alaska-airlines-plane-1-6990309-1722959685070.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9793139", "eventUri": "eng-9793139", {"uri": "8261165952", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "05:28:36", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T05:28:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T05:27:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9176470637321472, "url": "https://lasvegassun.com/news/2024/aug/05/witnesses-will-tell-a-federal-safety-board-about-t/", "title": "Witnesses will tell a federal safety board about the blowout on a Boeing 737 Max earlier this year", "body": "National Transportation Safety Board via AP, File\n\nThis photo released by the National Transportation Safety Board shows an opening in the fuselage where a door plug fell from Alaska Airlines Flight 1282, on Jan. 7, 2024, in Portland, Ore. On Tuesday, Aug. 6, 2024, the National Transportation Safety Board opens a two-day hearing on the blowout of a door plug from an Alaska Airlines flight traveling 16,000 feet above Oregon.\n\nBy David Koenig, Associated Press\n\nMonday, Aug. 5, 2024 | 10:21 p.m.\n\nInvestigators will question Boeing officials during a hearing starting Tuesday about the midflight blowout of a panel from a 737 Max, an accident that further tarnished the company's safety reputation and left it facing new legal jeopardy.\n\nThe two-day hearing could provide new insight into the Jan. 5 accident, which caused a loud boom and left a gaping hole in the side of the Alaska Airlines jet.\n\nThe National Transportation Safety Board has said in a preliminary report that four bolts that help secure the panel, which is call a door plug, were not replaced after a repair job in a Boeing factory, but the company has said the work was not documented. During the two-day hearing, safety board members are expected to question Boeing officials about the lack of paperwork that might have explained how such a potentially tragic mistake occurred.\n\n\"The NTSB wants to fill in the gaps of what is known about this incident and to put people on the record about it,\" said John Goglia, a former NTSB member. The agency will be looking to underscore Boeing's failures in following the process it had told the Federal Aviation Administration it was going to use in such cases, he said.\n\nThe safety board will not determine a probable cause after the hearing. That could take another year or longer. It is calling the unusually long hearing a fact-finding step.\n\nAmong the scheduled witnesses is Elizabeth Lund, who has been Boeing's senior vice president of quality -- a new position -- since February, and officials from Spirit AeroSystems, which makes fuselages for Max jets.\n\nSpirit installed the door plug -- a panel that fills a space created for an extra exit on some planes -- on the Alaska Airlines jet, but the panel was removed and the bolts taken off in a Boeing factory near Seattle to repair rivets.\n\nThe NTSB's agenda for the hearing includes testimony about manufacturing and inspections, the opening and closing of the door plug in the Boeing factory, safety systems at Boeing and Spirit, and the FAA's supervision of Boeing.\n\nFAA Administrator Mike Whitaker has conceded that his agency's oversight of the company \"was too hands-off -- too focused on paperwork audits and not focused enough on inspections.\" He has said that is changing.\n\nThe plane involved had been delivered to Alaska Airlines in late October and had made only about 150 flights. The airline stopped using the plane on flights to Hawaii after a warning light indicating a possible pressurization problem lit up on three different flights.\n\nThe accident on flight 1282 occurred minutes after takeoff from Portland, Oregon, as the plane flew at 16,000 feet (4,800 meters). Oxygen masks dropped during the rapid decompression, a few cell phones and other objects were swept through the hole in the plane, passengers were terrified by wind and roaring noise, but miraculously no one was injured.\n\nThe pilots landed safely back in Portland. The door plug was found in a high school science teacher's backyard in Cedar Hills, Oregon.\n\nNo one from the airline was called to testify this week before the NTSB. Goglia, the former safety board member, said that indicates the agency has determined \"that Alaska has no dirty hands in this.\"\n\nTension remains high between the NTSB and Boeing, however. Two months after the accident, board Chair Jennifer Homendy and Boeing got into a public argument over whether the company was cooperating with investigators.\n\nThat spat was largely smoothed over, but in June a Boeing executive angered the board by discussing the investigation with reporters and -- even worse in the agency's view -- suggesting that the NTSB was interested in finding someone to blame for the blowout.\n\nNTSB officials see their role as identifying the cause of accidents to prevent similar ones in the future. They are not prosecutors, and they fear that witnesses won't come forward if they think NTSB is looking for culprits.\n\nSo the NTSB issued a subpoena for Boeing representatives while stripping the company of its customary right to ask questions during the hearing.\n\nThe accident led to several investigations of Boeing, most of which are still underway.\n\nThe FBI has told passengers on the Alaska Airlines flight that they might be victims of a crime. The Justice Department pushed Boeing to plead guilty to a charge of conspiracy to commit fraud after finding that it failed to live up to a previous settlement related to regulatory approval of the Max.\n\nBoeing, which has yet to recover financially from two deadly crashes of Max jets in 2018 and 2019, has lost more than $25 billion since the start of 2019. Later this week, the company will get its third chief executive in 4 1/2 years.\n\nTestimony from NTSB hearings is not admissible in court, but lawyers suing Boeing over this and other accidents will be watching, knowing that they can seek depositions from witnesses to cover the same ground.\n\n\"Our cases are already solid -- door plugs shouldn't blow out during a flight,\" said one of those lawyers, Mark Lindquist of Seattle. \"Our cases grow even stronger, however, if the blowout was the result of habitually shoddy practices. Are jurors going to see this as negligence or something worse?\"", "source": {"uri": "lasvegassun.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Las Vegas Sun"}, "authors": [{"uri": During the two-day hearing, safety board members are expected to question Boeing officials about the lack of paperwork that might have explained how such a potentially tragic mistake occurred.\n\n\"The NTSB wants to fill in the gaps of what is known about this incident and to put people on the record about it,\" said John Goglia, a former NTSB member. The agency will be looking to underscore Boeing's failures in following the process it had told the Federal Aviation Administration it was going to use in such cases, he said.\n\nThe safety board will not determine a probable cause after the hearing. That could take another year or longer. It is calling the unusually long hearing a fact-finding step.\n\nAmong the scheduled witnesses is Elizabeth Lund, who has been Boeing's senior vice president of quality -- a new position -- since February, and officials from Spirit AeroSystems, which makes fuselages for Max jets.\n\nSpirit installed the door plug -- a panel that fills a space created for an extra exit on some planes -- on the Alaska Airlines jet, but the panel was removed and the bolts taken off in a Boeing factory near Seattle to repair rivets.\n\nThe NTSB's agenda for the hearing includes testimony about manufacturing and inspections, the opening and closing of the door plug in the Boeing factory, safety systems at Boeing and Spirit, and the FAA's supervision of Boeing.\n\nFAA Administrator Mike Whitaker has conceded that his agency's oversight of the company \"was too hands-off -- too focused on paperwork audits and not focused enough on inspections.\" He has said that is changing.\n\nThe plane involved had been delivered to Alaska Airlines in late October and had made only about 150 flights. The airline stopped using the plane on flights to Hawaii after a warning light indicating a possible pressurization problem lit up on three different flights.\n\nThe accident on flight 1282 occurred minutes after takeoff from Portland, Oregon, as the plane flew at 16,000 feet (4,800 meters). Oxygen masks dropped during the rapid decompression, a few cell phones and other objects were swept through the hole in the plane, passengers were terrified by wind and roaring noise, but miraculously no one was injured.\n\nThe pilots landed safely back in Portland. The door plug was found in a high school science teacher's backyard in Cedar Hills, Oregon.\n\nNo one from the airline was called to testify this week before the NTSB. Goglia, the former safety board member, said that indicates the agency has determined \"that Alaska has no dirty hands in this.\"\n\nTension remains high between the NTSB and Boeing, however. Two months after the accident, board Chair Jennifer Homendy and Boeing got into a public argument over whether the company was cooperating with investigators.\n\nThat spat was largely smoothed over, but in June a Boeing executive angered the board by discussing the investigation with reporters and -- even worse in the agency's view -- suggesting that the NTSB was interested in finding someone to blame for the blowout.\n\nNTSB officials see their role as identifying the cause of accidents to prevent similar ones in the future. They are not prosecutors, and they fear that witnesses won't come forward if they think NTSB is looking for culprits.\n\nSo the NTSB issued a subpoena for Boeing representatives while stripping the company of its customary right to ask questions during the hearing.\n\nThe accident led to several investigations of Boeing, most of which are still underway.\n\nThe FBI has told passengers on the Alaska Airlines flight that they might be victims of a crime. The Justice Department pushed Boeing to plead guilty to a charge of conspiracy to commit fraud after finding that it failed to live up to a previous settlement related to regulatory approval of the Max.\n\nBoeing, which has yet to recover financially from two deadly crashes of Max jets in 2018 and 2019, has lost more than $25 billion since the start of 2019. Later this week, the company will get its third chief executive in 4 1/2 years.\n\nTestimony from NTSB hearings is not admissible in court, but lawyers suing Boeing over this and other accidents will be watching, knowing that they can seek depositions from witnesses to cover the same ground.\n\n\"Our cases are already solid -- door plugs shouldn't blow out during a flight,\" said one of those lawyers, Mark Lindquist of Seattle. \"Our cases grow even stronger, however, if the blowout was the result of habitually shoddy practices. Are jurors going to see this as negligence or something worse?\"\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "2024-08-445911962", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "15:42:58", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T15:42:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T08:15:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9098039269447327, "url": "https://www.inc.com/associated-press/federal-safety-board-starts-grilling-boeing-executives.html", "title": "Federal Safety Board Starts Grilling Boeing Executives", "body": "A two-day National Transportation Safety Board hearing begins Tuesday, focusing on the faulty 737 MAX door panel that blew out midflight in January, sending the aircraft maker into a tailspin.\n\nInvestigators will question Boeing officials during a hearing starting Tuesday about the midflight blowout of a panel from a 737 Max, an accident that further tarnished the company's safety reputation and left it facing new legal jeopardy.\n\nThe two-day hearing could provide new insight into the Jan. 5 accident, which caused a loud boom and left a gaping hole in the side of the Alaska Airlines jet.\n\nThe National Transportation Safety Board has said in a preliminary report that four bolts that help secure the panel, which is called a door plug, were not replaced after a repair job in a Boeing factory, but the company has said the work was not documented. During the two-day hearing, safety board members are expected to question Boeing officials about the lack of paperwork that might have explained how such a potentially tragic mistake occurred.\n\n\"The NTSB wants to fill in the gaps of what is known about this incident and to put people on the record about it,\" said John Goglia, a former NTSB member. The agency will be looking to underscore Boeing's failures in following the process it had told the Federal Aviation Administration it was going to use in such cases, he said.\n\nThe safety board will not determine a probable cause after the hearing. That could take another year or longer. It is calling the unusually long hearing a fact-finding step.\n\nAmong the scheduled witnesses is Elizabeth Lund, who has been Boeing's senior vice president of quality--a new position--since February, and officials from Spirit AeroSystems, which makes fuselages for Max jets.\n\nSpirit installed the door plug--a panel that fills a space created for an extra exit on some planes--on the Alaska Airlines jet, but the panel was removed and the bolts taken off in a Boeing factory near Seattle to repair rivets.\n\nThe NTSB's agenda for the hearing includes testimony about manufacturing and inspections, the opening and closing of the door plug in the Boeing factory, safety systems at Boeing and Spirit, and the FAA's supervision of Boeing.\n\nFAA Administrator Mike Whitaker has conceded that his agency's oversight of the company \"was too hands-off--too focused on paperwork audits and not focused enough on inspections.\" He has said that is changing.\n\nThe plane involved had been delivered to Alaska Airlines in late October and had made only about 150 flights. The airline stopped using the plane on flights to Hawaii after a warning light indicating a possible pressurization problem lit up on three different flights.\n\nThe accident on flight 1282 occurred minutes after takeoff from Portland, Oregon, as the plane flew at 16,000 feet. Oxygen masks dropped during the rapid decompression, a few cell phones and other objects were swept through the hole in the plane, passengers were terrified by wind and roaring noise, but miraculously no one was injured.\n\nThe pilots landed safely back in Portland. The door plug was found in a high school science teacher's backyard in Cedar Hills, Oregon.\n\nNo one from the airline was called to testify this week before the NTSB. Goglia, the former safety board member, said that indicates the agency has determined \"that Alaska has no dirty hands in this.\"\n\nTension remains high between the NTSB and Boeing, however. Two months after the accident, board Chair Jennifer Homendy and Boeing got into a public argument over whether the company was cooperating with investigators.\n\nThat spat was largely smoothed over, but in June a Boeing executive angered the board by discussing the investigation with reporters and--even worse in the agency's view--suggesting that the NTSB was interested in finding someone to blame for the blowout.\n\nNTSB officials see their role as identifying the cause of accidents to prevent similar ones in the future. They are not prosecutors, and they fear that witnesses won't come forward if they think NTSB is looking for culprits.\n\nSo the NTSB issued a subpoena for Boeing representatives while stripping the company of its customary right to ask questions during the hearing.\n\nThe accident led to several investigations of Boeing, most of which are still underway.\n\nThe FBI has told passengers on the Alaska Airlines flight that they might be victims of a crime. The Justice Department pushed Boeing to plead guilty to a charge of conspiracy to commit fraud after finding that it failed to live up to a previous settlement related to regulatory approval of the Max.\n\nBoeing, which has yet to recover financially from two deadly crashes of Max jets in 2018 and 2019, has lost more than $25 billion since the start of 2019. Later this week, the company will get its third chief executive in 4 1/2 years.\n\nTestimony from NTSB hearings is not admissible in court, but lawyers suing Boeing over this and other accidents will be watching, knowing that they can seek depositions from witnesses to cover the same ground.\n\n\"Our cases are already solid--door plugs shouldn't blow out during a flight,\" said one of those lawyers, Mark Lindquist of Seattle. \"Our cases grow even stronger, however, if the blowout was the result of habitually shoddy practices. Are jurors going to see this as negligence or something worse?\"", "source": {"uri": "inc.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Inc.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@inc.com", "name": {"uri": "2024-08-445211212", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "04:28:48", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T04:28:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T17:38:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9098039269447327, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/oregon/articles/2024-08-06/witnesses-will-tell-a-federal-safety-board-about-the-blowout-on-a-boeing-737-max-earlier-this-year", "title": "Witnesses Will Tell a Federal Safety Board About the Blowout on a Boeing 737 Max Earlier This Year", "body": "Investigators will question Boeing officials during a hearing starting Tuesday about the midflight blowout of a panel from a 737 Max, an accident that further tarnished the company's safety reputation and left it facing new legal jeopardy.\n\nThe two-day hearing could provide new insight into the Jan. 5 accident, which caused a loud boom and left a gaping hole in the side of the Alaska Airlines jet.\n\nThe National Transportation Safety Board has said in a preliminary report that four bolts that help secure the panel, which is call a door plug, were not replaced after a repair job in a Boeing factory, but the company has said the work was not documented. During the two-day hearing, safety board members are expected to question Boeing officials about the lack of paperwork that might have explained how such a potentially tragic mistake occurred.\n\n\"The NTSB wants to fill in the gaps of what is known about this incident and to put people on the record about it,\" said John Goglia, a former NTSB member. The agency will be looking to underscore Boeing's failures in following the process it had told the Federal Aviation Administration it was going to use in such cases, he said.\n\nThe safety board will not determine a probable cause after the hearing. That could take another year or longer. It is calling the unusually long hearing a fact-finding step.\n\nAmong the scheduled witnesses is Elizabeth Lund, who has been Boeing's senior vice president of quality -- a new position -- since February, and officials from Spirit AeroSystems, which makes fuselages for Max jets.\n\nSpirit installed the door plug -- a panel that fills a space created for an extra exit on some planes -- on the Alaska Airlines jet, but the panel was removed and the bolts taken off in a Boeing factory near Seattle to repair rivets.\n\nThe NTSB's agenda for the hearing includes testimony about manufacturing and inspections, the opening and closing of the door plug in the Boeing factory, safety systems at Boeing and Spirit, and the FAA's supervision of Boeing.\n\nFAA Administrator Mike Whitaker has conceded that his agency's oversight of the company \"was too hands-off -- too focused on paperwork audits and not focused enough on inspections.\" He has said that is changing.\n\nThe plane involved had been delivered to Alaska Airlines in late October and had made only about 150 flights. The airline stopped using the plane on flights to Hawaii after a warning light indicating a possible pressurization problem lit up on three different flights.\n\nThe accident on flight 1282 occurred minutes after takeoff from Portland, Oregon, as the plane flew at 16,000 feet (4,800 meters). Oxygen masks dropped during the rapid decompression, a few cell phones and other objects were swept through the hole in the plane, passengers were terrified by wind and roaring noise, but miraculously no one was injured.\n\nThe pilots landed safely back in Portland. The door plug was found in a high school science teacher's backyard in Cedar Hills, Oregon.\n\nNo one from the airline was called to testify this week before the NTSB. Goglia, the former safety board member, said that indicates the agency has determined \"that Alaska has no dirty hands in this.\"\n\nTension remains high between the NTSB and Boeing, however. Two months after the accident, board Chair Jennifer Homendy and Boeing got into a public argument over whether the company was cooperating with investigators.\n\nThat spat was largely smoothed over, but in June a Boeing executive angered the board by discussing the investigation with reporters and -- even worse in the agency's view -- suggesting that the NTSB was interested in finding someone to blame for the blowout.\n\nNTSB officials see their role as identifying the cause of accidents to prevent similar ones in the future. They are not prosecutors, and they fear that witnesses won't come forward if they think NTSB is looking for culprits.\n\nSo the NTSB issued a subpoena for Boeing representatives while stripping the company of its customary right to ask questions during the hearing.\n\nThe accident led to several investigations of Boeing, most of which are still underway.\n\nThe FBI has told passengers on the Alaska Airlines flight that they might be victims of a crime. The Justice Department pushed Boeing to plead guilty to a charge of conspiracy to commit fraud after finding that it failed to live up to a previous settlement related to regulatory approval of the Max.\n\nBoeing, which has yet to recover financially from two deadly crashes of Max jets in 2018 and 2019, has lost more than $25 billion since the start of 2019. Later this week, the company will get its third chief executive in 4 1/2 years.\n\nTestimony from NTSB hearings is not admissible in court, but lawyers suing Boeing over this and other accidents will be watching, knowing that they can seek depositions from witnesses to cover the same ground.\n\n\"Our cases are already solid -- door plugs shouldn't blow out during a flight,\" said one of those lawyers, Mark Lindquist of Seattle. \"Our cases grow even stronger, however, if the blowout was the result of habitually shoddy practices. Are jurors going to see this as negligence or something worse?\"\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9793139", "eventUri": "eng-9793139", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "-01-05", "textStart": 296, "textEnd": 302}], "sentiment": {"uri": "2024-08-445229404", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "04:54:19", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T04:54:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T04:01:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9058823585510254, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/witnesses-will-tell-a-federal-safety-board-about-the-blowout-on-a-boeing-737-max/article_d95d6d8b-fa17-57d7-9121-28789dfafb37.html", "title": "Witnesses will tell a federal safety board about the blowout on a Boeing 737 Max earlier this year", "body": "The National Transportation Safety Board is about to hold a two-day hearing into the blowout of a panel from the side of a Boeing 737 Max airliner\n\nInvestigators will question Boeing officials during a hearing starting Tuesday about the midflight blowout of a panel from a 737 Max, an accident that further tarnished the company's safety reputation and left it facing new legal jeopardy.\n\nThe two-day hearing could provide new insight into the Jan. 5 accident, which caused a loud boom and left a gaping hole in the side of the Alaska Airlines jet.\n\nThe National Transportation Safety Board has said in a preliminary report that four bolts that help secure the panel, which is call a door plug, were not replaced after a repair job in a Boeing factory, but the company has said the work was not documented. During the two-day hearing, safety board members are expected to question Boeing officials about the lack of paperwork that might have explained how such a potentially tragic mistake occurred.\n\n\"The NTSB wants to fill in the gaps of what is known about this incident and to put people on the record about it,\" said John Goglia, a former NTSB member. The agency will be looking to underscore Boeing's failures in following the process it had told the Federal Aviation Administration it was going to use in such cases, he said.\n\nThe safety board will not determine a probable cause after the hearing. That could take another year or longer. It is calling the unusually long hearing a fact-finding step.\n\nAmong the scheduled witnesses is Elizabeth Lund, who has been Boeing's senior vice president of quality -- a new position -- since February, and officials from Spirit AeroSystems, which makes fuselages for Max jets.\n\nSpirit installed the door plug -- a panel that fills a space created for an extra exit on some planes -- on the Alaska Airlines jet, but the panel was removed and the bolts taken off in a Boeing factory near Seattle to repair rivets.\n\nThe NTSB's agenda for the hearing includes testimony about manufacturing and inspections, the opening and closing of the door plug in the Boeing factory, safety systems at Boeing and Spirit, and the FAA's supervision of Boeing.\n\nFAA Administrator Mike Whitaker has conceded that his agency's oversight of the company \"was too hands-off -- too focused on paperwork audits and not focused enough on inspections.\" He has said that is changing.\n\nThe plane involved had been delivered to Alaska Airlines in late October and had made only about 150 flights. The airline stopped using the plane on flights to Hawaii after a warning light indicating a possible pressurization problem lit up on three different flights.\n\nThe accident on flight 1282 occurred minutes after takeoff from Portland, Oregon, as the plane flew at 16,000 feet (4,800 meters). Oxygen masks dropped during the rapid decompression, a few cell phones and other objects were swept through the hole in the plane, passengers were terrified by wind and roaring noise, but miraculously no one was injured.\n\nThe pilots landed safely back in Portland. The door plug was found in a high school science teacher's backyard in Cedar Hills, Oregon.\n\nNo one from the airline was called to testify this week before the NTSB. Goglia, the former safety board member, said that indicates the agency has determined \"that Alaska has no dirty hands in this.\"\n\nTension remains high between the NTSB and Boeing, however. Two months after the accident, board Chair Jennifer Homendy and Boeing got into a public argument over whether the company was cooperating with investigators.\n\nThat spat was largely smoothed over, but in June a Boeing executive angered the board by discussing the investigation with reporters and -- even worse in the agency's view -- suggesting that the NTSB was interested in finding someone to blame for the blowout.\n\nNTSB officials see their role as identifying the cause of accidents to prevent similar ones in the future. They are not prosecutors, and they fear that witnesses won't come forward if they think NTSB is looking for culprits.\n\nSo the NTSB issued a subpoena for Boeing representatives while stripping the company of its customary right to ask questions during the hearing.\n\nThe accident led to several investigations of Boeing, most of which are still underway.\n\nThe FBI has told passengers on the Alaska Airlines flight that they might be victims of a crime. The Justice Department pushed Boeing to plead guilty to a charge of conspiracy to commit fraud after finding that it failed to live up to a previous settlement related to regulatory approval of the Max.\n\nBoeing, which has yet to recover financially from two deadly crashes of Max jets in 2018 and 2019, has lost more than $25 billion since the start of 2019. Later this week, the company will get its third chief executive in 4 1/2 years.\n\nTestimony from NTSB hearings is not admissible in court, but lawyers suing Boeing over this and other accidents will be watching, knowing that they can seek depositions from witnesses to cover the same ground.\n\n\"Our cases are already solid -- door plugs shouldn't blow out during a flight,\" said one of those lawyers, Mark Lindquist of Seattle. \"Our cases grow even stronger, however, if the blowout was the result of habitually shoddy practices. Are jurors going to see this as negligence or something worse?\"\n\nMore from this section\n\nAttorney Jenna Sutter Joins All Injuries Law Firm\n\nGoogle illegally maintains monopoly over internet search, judge rules\n\nThe UN Acknowledges Foundation for a Drug-Free World With Consultative Status", "source": {"uri": "kulr8.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KULR-8 Local News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "david_koenig@kulr8.com", "name": "David Koenig", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_Everett_Factory", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Boeing Everett Factory"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alaska_Airlines", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Alaska Airlines"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_737_MAX", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Boeing 737 MAX"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Boeing"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Transportation_Safety_Board", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "National Transportation Safety Board"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jet_aircraft", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Jet aircraft"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Aviation_Administration", "type": "wiki", "eventUri": "eng-9793139", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "-01-05", "textStart": 444, "textEnd": 450}], "sentiment": -0.02745098039215688, "wgt": 231, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8261098096", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "04:24:46", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T04:24:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T04:24:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9058823585510254, "url": "https://www.wral.com/story/witnesses-will-tell-a-federal-safety-board-about-the-blowout-on-a-boeing-737-max-earlier-this-year/21562459/", "title": "Witnesses will tell a federal safety board about the blowout on a Boeing 737 Max earlier this year", "body": "Investigators will question Boeing officials during a hearing starting Tuesday about the midflight blowout of a panel from a 737 Max, an accident that further tarnished the company's safety reputation and left it facing new legal jeopardy.\n\nInvestigators will question Boeing officials during a hearing starting Tuesday about the midflight blowout of a panel from a 737 Max, an accident that further tarnished the company's safety reputation and left it facing new legal jeopardy.\n\nThe two-day hearing could provide new insight into the Jan. 5 accident, which caused a loud boom and left a gaping hole in the side of the Alaska Airlines jet.\n\nThe National Transportation Safety Board has said in a preliminary report that four bolts that help secure the panel, which is call a door plug, were not replaced after a repair job in a Boeing factory, but the company has said the work was not documented. During the two-day hearing, safety board members are expected to question Boeing officials about the lack of paperwork that might have explained how such a potentially tragic mistake occurred.\n\n\"The NTSB wants to fill in the gaps of what is known about this incident and to put people on the record about it,\" said John Goglia, a former NTSB member. The agency will be looking to underscore Boeing's failures in following the process it had told the Federal Aviation Administration it was going to use in such cases, he said.\n\nThe safety board will not determine a probable cause after the hearing. That could take another year or longer. It is calling the unusually long hearing a fact-finding step.\n\nAmong the scheduled witnesses is Elizabeth Lund, who has been Boeing's senior vice president of quality -- a new position -- since February, and officials from Spirit AeroSystems, which makes fuselages for Max jets.\n\nSpirit installed the door plug -- a panel that fills a space created for an extra exit on some planes -- on the Alaska Airlines jet, but the panel was removed and the bolts taken off in a Boeing factory near Seattle to repair rivets.\n\nThe NTSB's agenda for the hearing includes testimony about manufacturing and inspections, the opening and closing of the door plug in the Boeing factory, safety systems at Boeing and Spirit, and the FAA's supervision of Boeing.\n\nFAA Administrator Mike Whitaker has conceded that his agency's oversight of the company \"was too hands-off -- too focused on paperwork audits and not focused enough on inspections.\" He has said that is changing.\n\nThe plane involved had been delivered to Alaska Airlines in late October and had made only about 150 flights. The airline stopped using the plane on flights to Hawaii after a warning light indicating a possible pressurization problem lit up on three different flights.\n\nThe accident on flight 1282 occurred minutes after takeoff from Portland, Oregon, as the plane flew at 16,000 feet (4,800 meters). Oxygen masks dropped during the rapid decompression, a few cell phones and other objects were swept through the hole in the plane, passengers were terrified by wind and roaring noise, but miraculously no one was injured.\n\nThe pilots landed safely back in Portland. The door plug was found in a high school science teacher's backyard in Cedar Hills, Oregon.\n\nNo one from the airline was called to testify this week before the NTSB. Goglia, the former safety board member, said that indicates the agency has determined \"that Alaska has no dirty hands in this.\"\n\nTension remains high between the NTSB and Boeing, however. Two months after the accident, board Chair Jennifer Homendy and Boeing got into a public argument over whether the company was cooperating with investigators.\n\nThat spat was largely smoothed over, but in June a Boeing executive angered the board by discussing the investigation with reporters and -- even worse in the agency's view -- suggesting that the NTSB was interested in finding someone to blame for the blowout.\n\nNTSB officials see their role as identifying the cause of accidents to prevent similar ones in the future. They are not prosecutors, and they fear that witnesses won't come forward if they think NTSB is looking for culprits.\n\nSo the NTSB issued a subpoena for Boeing representatives while stripping the company of its customary right to ask questions during the hearing.\n\nThe accident led to several investigations of Boeing, most of which are still underway.\n\nThe FBI has told passengers on the Alaska Airlines flight that they might be victims of a crime. The Justice Department pushed Boeing to plead guilty to a charge of conspiracy to commit fraud after finding that it failed to live up to a previous settlement related to regulatory approval of the Max.\n\nBoeing, which has yet to recover financially from two deadly crashes of Max jets in 2018 and 2019, has lost more than $25 billion since the start of 2019. Later this week, the company will get its third chief executive in 4 1/2 years.\n\nTestimony from NTSB hearings is not admissible in court, but lawyers suing Boeing over this and other accidents will be watching, knowing that they can seek depositions from witnesses to cover the same ground.\n\n\"Our cases are already solid -- door plugs shouldn't blow out during a flight,\" said one of those lawyers, Mark Lindquist of Seattle. \"Our cases grow even stronger, however, if the blowout was the result of habitually shoddy practices. Are jurors going to see this as negligence or something worse?\"", "source": {"uri": "wral.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WRAL"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-445826754", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "14:24:23", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T14:24:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T13:51:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9058823585510254, "url": "https://www.newstimes.com/business/article/witnesses-will-tell-a-federal-safety-board-about-19622225.php", "title": "Witnesses tell a federal safety board about the blowout on a Boeing 737 Max earlier this year", "body": "Investigators are questioning Boeing officials in hearings this week about the midflight blowout of a panel from a 737 Max, an accident that further tarnished the company's safety reputation and left it facing new legal jeopardy.\n\nThe National Transportation Safety Board's two-day hearing, which began Tuesday morning, could provide new insight into the Jan. 5 accident that caused a loud boom and left a gaping hole in the side of the Alaska Airlines jet.\n\n\"This was quite traumatic to the crew and passengers,\" NTSB Chair Jennifer Homendy said as the hearing began Tuesday, speaking to anyone who may have been on the flight or knew someone aboard. \"We are so sorry for all that you experienced during this very traumatic event.\"\n\nThe NTSB said in a preliminary report that four bolts that help secure the panel, which is call a door plug, were not replaced after a repair job in a Boeing factory, but the company has said the work was not documented. During the hearing, safety board members are expected to question Boeing officials about the lack of paperwork that might have explained how such a potentially tragic mistake occurred.\n\n\"The NTSB wants to fill in the gaps of what is known about this incident and to put people on the record about it,\" said John Goglia, a former NTSB member. The agency will be looking to underscore Boeing's failures in following the process it had told the Federal Aviation Administration it was going to use in such cases, he said.\n\nThe safety board will not determine a probable cause after the hearing. That could take another year or longer. It is calling the unusually long hearing a fact-finding step.\n\nAmong the scheduled witnesses is Elizabeth Lund, who has been Boeing's senior vice president of quality -- a new position -- since February, and officials from Spirit AeroSystems, which makes fuselages for Max jets.\n\nSpirit installed the door plug -- a panel that fills a space created for an extra exit on some planes -- on the Alaska Airlines jet, but the panel was removed and the bolts taken off in a Boeing factory near Seattle to repair rivets.\n\nThe NTSB's agenda for the hearing includes testimony about manufacturing and inspections, the opening and closing of the door plug in the Boeing factory, safety systems at Boeing and Spirit, and the FAA's supervision of Boeing.\n\nFAA Administrator Mike Whitaker has conceded that his agency's oversight of the company \"was too hands-off -- too focused on paperwork audits and not focused enough on inspections.\" He has said that is changing.\n\nThe plane involved had been delivered to Alaska Airlines in late October and had made only about 150 flights. The airline stopped using the plane on flights to Hawaii after a warning light indicating a possible pressurization problem lit up on three different flights.\n\nThe accident on flight 1282 occurred minutes after takeoff from Portland, Oregon, as the plane flew at 16,000 feet (4,800 meters). Oxygen masks dropped during the rapid decompression, a few cell phones and other objects were swept through the hole in the plane, passengers were terrified by wind and roaring noise, but miraculously there were no major injuries. Homendy said Tuesday that seven passengers and one flight attendant received minor physical injuries.\n\nThe pilots landed safely back in Portland. The door plug was found in a high school science teacher's backyard in Cedar Hills, Oregon.\n\nNo one from the airline was called to testify this week before the NTSB. Goglia, the former safety board member, said that indicates the agency has determined \"that Alaska has no dirty hands in this.\"\n\nTension remains high between the NTSB and Boeing, however. Two months after the accident, board Chair Jennifer Homendy and Boeing got into a public argument over whether the company was cooperating with investigators.\n\nThat spat was largely smoothed over, but in June a Boeing executive angered the board by discussing the investigation with reporters and -- even worse in the agency's view -- suggesting that the NTSB was interested in finding someone to blame for the blowout.\n\nNTSB officials see their role as identifying the cause of accidents to prevent similar ones in the future. They are not prosecutors, and they fear that witnesses won't come forward if they think NTSB is looking for culprits.\n\nSo the NTSB issued a subpoena for Boeing representatives while stripping the company of its customary right to ask questions during the hearing.\n\nThe accident led to several investigations of Boeing, most of which are still underway.\n\nThe FBI has told passengers on the Alaska Airlines flight that they might be victims of a crime. The Justice Department pushed Boeing to plead guilty to a charge of conspiracy to commit fraud after finding that it failed to live up to a previous settlement related to regulatory approval of the Max.\n\nBoeing, which has yet to recover financially from two deadly crashes of Max jets in 2018 and 2019, has lost more than $25 billion since the start of 2019. Later this week, the company will get its third chief executive in 4 1/2 years.\n\nTestimony from NTSB hearings is not admissible in court, but lawyers suing Boeing over this and other accidents will be watching, knowing that they can seek depositions from witnesses to cover the same ground.\n\n\"Our cases are already solid -- door plugs shouldn't blow out during a flight,\" said one of those lawyers, Mark Lindquist of Seattle. \"Our cases grow even stronger, however, if the blowout was the result of habitually shoddy practices. "https://s.hdnux.com/photos/01/41/27/11/25522785/6/rawImage.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9793139", "eventUri": "eng-9793139", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "-01-05", "textStart": 355, "textEnd": 361}], "sentiment": -0.0980392156862745, "wgt": 231, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8261110329", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "04:43:56", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T04:43:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T04:36:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9058823585510254, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13712875/Witnesses-tell-federal-safety-board-blowout-Boeing-737-Max-earlier-year.html", "title": "Witnesses will tell a federal safety board about the blowout on a...", "body": "Investigators will question Boeing officials during a hearing starting Tuesday about the midflight blowout of a panel from a 737 Max, an accident that further tarnished the company's safety reputation and left it facing new legal jeopardy.\n\nThe two-day hearing could provide new insight into the Jan. 5 accident, which caused a loud boom and left a gaping hole in the side of the Alaska Airlines jet.\n\nThe National Transportation Safety Board has said in a preliminary report that four bolts that help secure the panel, which is call a door plug, were not replaced after a repair job in a Boeing factory, but the company has said the work was not documented. During the two-day hearing, safety board members are expected to question Boeing officials about the lack of paperwork that might have explained how such a potentially tragic mistake occurred.\n\n\"The NTSB wants to fill in the gaps of what is known about this incident and to put people on the record about it,\" said John Goglia, a former NTSB member. The agency will be looking to underscore Boeing's failures in following the process it had told the Federal Aviation Administration it was going to use in such cases, he said.\n\nThe safety board will not determine a probable cause after the hearing. That could take another year or longer. It is calling the unusually long hearing a fact-finding step.\n\nAmong the scheduled witnesses is Elizabeth Lund, who has been Boeing's senior vice president of quality - a new position - since February, and officials from Spirit AeroSystems, which makes fuselages for Max jets.\n\nFILE - This photo released by the National Transportation Safety Board shows an opening in the fuselage where a door plug fell from Alaska Airlines Flight 1282, on Jan. 7, 2024, in Portland, Ore. On Tuesday, Aug. 6, 2024, the National Transportation Safety Board opens a two-day hearing on the blowout of a door plug from an Alaska Airlines flight traveling 16,000 feet above Oregon. (National Transportation Safety Board via AP, File)\n\nSpirit installed the door plug - a panel that fills a space created for an extra exit on some planes - on the Alaska Airlines jet, but the panel was removed and the bolts taken off in a Boeing factory near Seattle to repair rivets.\n\nThe NTSB\u00b4s agenda for the hearing includes testimony about manufacturing and inspections, the opening and closing of the door plug in the Boeing factory, safety systems at Boeing and Spirit, and the FAA's supervision of Boeing.\n\nFAA Administrator Mike Whitaker has conceded that his agency's oversight of the company \"was too hands-off - too focused on paperwork audits and not focused enough on inspections.\" He has said that is changing.\n\nThe plane involved had been delivered to Alaska Airlines in late October and had made only about 150 flights. The airline stopped using the plane on flights to Hawaii after a warning light indicating a possible pressurization problem lit up on three different flights.\n\nThe accident on flight 1282 occurred minutes after takeoff from Portland, Oregon, as the plane flew at 16,000 feet (4,800 meters). Oxygen masks dropped during the rapid decompression, a few cell phones and other objects were swept through the hole in the plane, passengers were terrified by wind and roaring noise, but miraculously no one was injured.\n\nThe pilots landed safely back in Portland. The door plug was found in a high school science teacher's backyard in Cedar Hills, Oregon.\n\nNo one from the airline was called to testify this week before the NTSB. Goglia, the former safety board member, said that indicates the agency has determined \"that Alaska has no dirty hands in this.\"\n\nTension remains high between the NTSB and Boeing, however. Two months after the accident, board Chair Jennifer Homendy and Boeing got into a public argument over whether the company was cooperating with investigators.\n\nThat spat was largely smoothed over, but in June a Boeing executive angered the board by discussing the investigation with reporters and - even worse in the agency's view - suggesting that the NTSB was interested in finding someone to blame for the blowout.\n\nNTSB officials see their role as identifying the cause of accidents to prevent similar ones in the future. They are not prosecutors, and they fear that witnesses won't come forward if they think NTSB is looking for culprits.\n\nSo the NTSB issued a subpoena for Boeing representatives while stripping the company of its customary right to ask questions during the hearing.\n\nThe accident led to several investigations of Boeing, most of which are still underway.\n\nThe FBI has told passengers on the Alaska Airlines flight that they might be victims of a crime. The Justice Department pushed Boeing to plead guilty to a charge of conspiracy to commit fraud after finding that it failed to live up to a previous settlement related to regulatory approval of the Max.\n\nBoeing, which has yet to recover financially from two deadly crashes of Max jets in 2018 and 2019, has lost more than $25 billion since the start of 2019. Later this week, the company will get its third chief executive in 4 1/2 years.\n\nTestimony from NTSB hearings is not admissible in court, but lawyers suing Boeing over this and other accidents will be watching, knowing that they can seek depositions from witnesses to cover the same ground.\n\n\"Our cases are already solid - door plugs shouldn\u00b4t blow out during a flight,\" said one of those lawyers, Mark Lindquist of Seattle. \"Our cases grow even stronger, however, if the blowout was the result of habitually shoddy practices. Are jurors going to see this as negligence or something worse?\"\n\nFILE - The door plug from the Alaska Airlines Flight 1282's Boeing 737-9 MAX airplane is shown at the National Transportation Safety Board laboratory, in Washington, July 30, 2024. On Tuesday, August 6, 2024, the National Transportation Safety Board opens a two-day hearing on the blowout of the door plug from the Alaska Airlines flight traveling 16,000 feet above Oregon. (AP Photo/Manuel Balce Ceneta, File)", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri":
