{"uri": "8262343177", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "19:12:34", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T19:12:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T19:11:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://mynorthwest.com/3974224/witness-before-federal-safety-board-testifies-blowout-boeing-737-max-earlier-this-year/", "title": "Witness before federal safety board testifies about blowout on a Boeing 737 Max earlier this year", "body": "\"The NTSB wants to fill in the gaps of what is known about this incident and to put people on the record about it,\" said John Goglia, a former NTSB member. The agency will be looking to underscore Boeing's failures in following the process it had told the Federal Aviation Administration it was going to use in such cases, he said.\n\nThe safety board will not determine a probable cause after the hearing. That could take another year or longer. It is calling the unusually long hearing a \"fact-finding\" step.\n\nThe first witnesses called Tuesday included Elizabeth Lund, Boeing's senior vice president of quality -- a new position -- since February.\n\nBoeing supplier Spirit AeroSystems installed the door plug, a panel on many 737s that fills a cutout left for an extra exit required on some planes. The plug on the Alaska Airlines jet was removed and the bolts were taken off in a Boeing factory to repair rivets.\n\nWitnesses for Spirit and Boeing testified about safety systems and inspection processes. Lund said production of Max jets dropped below 10 per month after the Alaska Airlines blowout and has increased. but remains under 30 per month.\n\nLater Tuesday, witnesses are expected to testify about the opening and closing of the door plug and the FAA's oversight of Boeing.\n\nFAA Administrator Mike Whitaker has conceded that his agency's oversight of the company \"was too hands-off -- too focused on paperwork audits and not focused enough on inspections.\" He has said that is changing.\n\nMore on Boeing: Boeing gets hammered by NTSB for violation of investigative regulations\n\nThe plane involved had been delivered to Alaska Airlines in late October and had made only about 150 flights. The airline stopped using the plane on flights to Hawaii after a warning light indicating a possible pressurization problem lit up on three different flights.\n\nThe accident on flight 1282 occurred minutes after takeoff from Portland, Oregon, as the plane flew at 16,000 feet (4,800 meters). Oxygen masks dropped during the rapid decompression, a few cell phones and other objects were swept through the hole in the plane, passengers were terrified by the wind and roaring noise, but miraculously there were no major injuries. Homendy said Tuesday that seven passengers and one flight attendant received minor physical injuries.\n\nThe pilots landed safely back in Portland. The door plug was found in a high school science teacher's backyard in Cedar Hills, Oregon.\n\nNo one from the airline was called to testify this week before the NTSB. Goglia, the former safety board member, said that indicates the agency has determined \"that Alaska has no dirty hands in this.\"\n\nTension remains high between the NTSB and Boeing, however. Two months after the accident, board Chair Jennifer Homendy and Boeing got into a public argument over whether the company was cooperating with investigators.\n\nThat spat was largely smoothed over, but in June a Boeing executive angered the board by discussing the investigation with reporters and -- even worse in the agency's view -- suggesting that the NTSB was interested in finding someone to blame for the blowout.\n\nNTSB officials see their role as identifying the cause of accidents to prevent similar ones in the future. They are not prosecutors, and they fear that witnesses won't come forward if they think NTSB is looking for culprits.\n\nSo the NTSB issued a subpoena for Boeing representatives while stripping the company of its customary right to ask questions during the hearing.\n\nThe accident led to several investigations of Boeing, most of which are still underway.\n\nMore from Boeing: Starliner's return to Earth delayed indefinitely as it troubleshoots glitches\n\nThe FBI has told passengers on the Alaska Airlines flight that they might be victims of a crime. The Justice Department pushed Boeing to plead guilty to a charge of conspiracy to commit fraud after finding that it failed to live up to a previous settlement related to regulatory approval of the Max.\n\nBoeing, which has yet to recover financially from two deadly crashes of Max jets in 2018 and 2019, has lost more than $25 billion since the start of 2019. Later this week, the company will get its third chief executive in 4 1/2 years.\n\nTestimony from NTSB hearings is not admissible in court, but lawyers suing Boeing over this and other accidents will be watching, knowing that they can seek depositions from witnesses to cover the same ground.\n\n\"Our cases are already solid -- door plugs shouldn't blow out during a flight,\" said one of those lawyers, Mark Lindquist of Seattle. \"Our cases grow even stronger, however, if the blowout was the result of habitually shoddy practices. {"uri": "8261947070", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "14:09:34", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T14:09:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T14:07:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-witnesses-will-tell-a-federal-safety-board-about-the-blowout-on-a-boeing-737-max-earlier-this-year-6168967.html", "title": "World News | Witnesses Will Tell a Federal Safety Board About the Blowout on a Boeing 737 Max Earlier This Year | LatestLY", "body": "Get latest articles and stories on World at LatestLY. Investigators are questioning Boeing officials in hearings this week about the midflight blowout of a panel from a 737 Max, an accident that further tarnished the company's safety reputation and left it facing new legal jeopardy.\n\nWashington, Aug 6 (AP) Investigators are questioning Boeing officials in hearings this week about the midflight blowout of a panel from a 737 Max, an accident that further tarnished the company's safety reputation and left it facing new legal jeopardy.\n\nThe National Transportation Safety Board's two-day hearing, which began Tuesday morning, could provide new insight into the January 5 accident that caused a loud boom and left a gaping hole in the side of the Alaska Airlines jet.\n\nAlso Read | 'Hindus Are Very Afraid': Bangladesh ISKCON General Secretary Charu Chandra Das Brahmachari Seek's India's Help Amid Unrest (Watch Video).\n\n\"This was quite traumatic to the crew and passengers,\" NTSB Chair Jennifer Homendy said in opening statements Tuesday, noting that there are also injuries \"we can't see\" that may have lasting impacts on peoples' lives.\n\nSpeaking to anyone who may may have been on the flight or knew someone aboard Homendy said, \"On behalf of the entire agency, we are so sorry for all that you experienced during this very traumatic event.\"\n\nAlso Read | Hiroshima, Nagasaki Atomic Bombings: Lok Sabha Pays Tributes to Victims of Nuclear Bomb Attack in Japanese Cities in August 1945.\n\nThe NTSB said in a preliminary report that four bolts that help secure the panel, which is call a door plug, were not replaced after a repair job in a Boeing factory, but the company has said the work was not documented.\n\nDuring the hearing, safety board members are expected to question Boeing officials about the lack of paperwork that might have explained how such a potentially tragic mistake occurred.\n\n\"The NTSB wants to fill in the gaps of what is known about this incident and to put people on the record about it,\" said John Goglia, a former NTSB member.\n\nThe agency will be looking to underscore Boeing's failures in following the process it had told the Federal Aviation Administration it was going to use in such cases, he said.\n\nThe safety board will not determine a probable cause after the hearing. That could take another year or longer. It is calling the unusually long hearing a fact-finding step.\n\nAmong the scheduled witnesses is Elizabeth Lund, who has been Boeing's senior vice president of quality -- a new position -- since February, and officials from Spirit AeroSystems, which makes fuselages for Max jets.\n\nSpirit installed the door plug -- a panel that fills a space created for an extra exit on some planes -- on the Alaska Airlines jet, but the panel was removed and the bolts taken off in a Boeing factory near Seattle to repair rivets.\n\nThe NTSB's agenda for the hearing includes testimony about manufacturing and inspections, the opening and closing of the door plug in the Boeing factory, safety systems at Boeing and Spirit, and the FAA's supervision of Boeing.\n\nFAA Administrator Mike Whitaker has conceded that his agency's oversight of the company \"was too hands-off -- too focused on paperwork audits and not focused enough on inspections.\" He has said that is changing.\n\nThe plane involved had been delivered to Alaska Airlines in late October and had made only about 150 flights. The airline stopped using the plane on flights to Hawaii after a warning light indicating a possible pressurization problem lit up on three different flights.\n\nThe accident on flight 1282 occurred minutes after takeoff from Portland, Oregon, as the plane flew at 16,000 feet (4,800 metres).\n\nOxygen masks dropped during the rapid decompression, a few cell phones and other objects were swept through the hole in the plane, passengers were terrified by wind and roaring noise, but miraculously there were no major injuries. Homendy said Tuesday that seven passengers and one flight attendant received minor physical injuries.\n\nThe pilots landed safely back in Portland. The door plug was found in a high school science teacher's backyard in Cedar Hills, Oregon.\n\nNo one from the airline was called to testify this week before the NTSB. Goglia, the former safety board member, said that indicates the agency has determined \"that Alaska has no dirty hands in this.\"\n\nTension remains high between the NTSB and Boeing, however. Two months after the accident, board Chair Jennifer Homendy and Boeing got into a public argument over whether the company was cooperating with investigators.\n\nThat spat was largely smoothed over, but in June a Boeing executive angered the board by discussing the investigation with reporters and -- even worse in the agency's view -- suggesting that the NTSB was interested in finding someone to blame for the blowout.\n\nNTSB officials see their role as identifying the cause of accidents to prevent similar ones in the future. They are not prosecutors, and they fear that witnesses won't come forward if they think NTSB is looking for culprits.\n\nSo the NTSB issued a subpoena for Boeing representatives while stripping the company of its customary right to ask questions during the hearing.\n\nThe accident led to several investigations of Boeing, most of which are still underway.\n\nThe FBI has told passengers on the Alaska Airlines flight that they might be victims of a crime. The Justice Department pushed Boeing to plead guilty to a charge of conspiracy to commit fraud after finding that it failed to live up to a previous settlement related to regulatory approval of the Max.\n\nBoeing, which has yet to recover financially from two deadly crashes of Max jets in 2018 and 2019, has lost more than $25 billion since the start of 2019. Later this week, the company will get its third chief executive in 4 1/2 years.\n\nTestimony from NTSB hearings is not admissible in court, but lawyers suing Boeing over this and other accidents will be watching, knowing that they can seek depositions from witnesses to cover the same ground.\n\n\"Our cases are already solid -- door plugs shouldn't blow out during a flight,\" said one of those lawyers, Mark Lindquist of Seattle. \"Our cases grow even stronger, however, if the blowout was the result of habitually shoddy practices. Are jurors going to see this as negligence or something worse?\" (AP)", "source": {"uri": "latestly.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "LatestLY"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-446049888", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "18:17:06", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T18:17:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T15:57:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/business/hearing-seeks-insight-into-blowout-on-a-boeing-jet-that-pilots-said-threw-the-flight-into-chaos-1.6990299", "title": "Hearing seeks insight into blowout on a Boeing jet that pilots said threw the flight into 'chaos'", "body": "The midflight blowout of a panel from a Boeing 737 Max jet was so powerful that it blew open the plane's cockpit door and tore off the co-pilot's headset, and federal investigators began questioning officials from Boeing and its key supplier on Tuesday to understand how the accident occurred.\n\n\"It was chaos,\" the co-pilot of that Alaska Airlines flight on Jan. 5 flight said in documents released by the National Transportation Safety Board.\n\nComments of the pilots, factory workers at Boeing and other people were released as the safety board held a rare investigative hearing into the blowout, an accident that further tarnished Boeing's safety reputation and left it facing new legal jeopardy.\n\nThe U.S. National Transportation Safety Board's (NTSB) two-day hearing, which began Tuesday, could provide new insight into accident that caused a loud boom and left a gaping hole in the side of the Alaska Airlines jet. The NTSB also released more than 3,000 pages of documents with details about the incident.\n\nThe captain described it as \"an explosive experience\" and said he couldn't communicate with flight attendants, according to the documents. On the intercom, he heard flight attendants talking about a hole in the plane. He decided to land the plane as quickly as possible.\n\nThe pilots landed safely back in Portland. The door plug was found in a high school science teacher's backyard in Cedar Hills, Ore.\n\nThe accident on flight 1282 occurred minutes after takeoff from Portland, Ore., as the plane flew at 16,000 feet (4,800 metres). Oxygen masks dropped during the rapid decompression, a few cell phones and other objects were swept through the hole in the plane, passengers were terrified by wind and roaring noise, but miraculously there were no major injuries.\n\n\"This was quite traumatic to the crew and passengers,\" NTSB Chair Jennifer Homendy said as Tuesday's hearing began, speaking to anyone who may have been on the flight or knew someone aboard. \"We are so sorry for all that you experienced during this very traumatic event.\"\n\nHomendy said seven passengers and one flight attendant received minor physical injuries.\n\nThe NTSB said in a preliminary report that four bolts that help secure the panel, which is called a door plug, were not replaced after a repair job in a Boeing factory, but the company has said the work was not documented. During the hearing, safety board members are expected to question Boeing officials about the lack of paperwork that might have explained how such a potentially tragic mistake occurred.\n\nThe door plug from the Alaska Airlines Flight 1282's Boeing 737-9 MAX airplane is shown at the National Transportation Safety Board laboratory, in Washington, July 30, 2024. (AP Photo/Manuel Balce Ceneta, File)\n\nThe safety board will not determine a probable cause after the hearing. That could take another year or longer. It is calling the unusually long hearing a \"fact-finding\" step.\n\nBoeing supplier Spirit AeroSystems installed the door plug, a panel on many 737s that fills a cutout left for an extra exit required on some planes. The plug on the Alaska Airlines jet was removed and the bolts taken off in a Boeing factory to repair rivets.\n\nAmong the first witnesses called Tuesday was Elizabeth Lund, who has served as Boeing's senior vice president of quality -- a new position -- since February.\n\nWitnesses for Spirit and Boeing testified about safety systems and inspection processes. Lund said production of Max jets dropped below 10 per month after the Alaska Airlines blowout and has increased, but remains under 30 per month.\n\nLund and others also discussed the impact of COVID-19 on production and worker experience. Spirit Senior Vice President Terry George said that just five years ago, 95 per cent of its factory employees had worked with sheet metal, but now it is five per cent, and they must get more training in drilling holes and installing fasteners in aircraft bodies.\n\nBefore the pandemic, Lund added, most new hires at Boeing factories had aerospace experience, often in the military, but \"coming out of COVID ... we found that considerably more of our employees did not have that aerospace experience.\" She said the company has improved training since the January accident.\n\nBut others remained skeptical. \"We have never been impressed with Boeing's training at all,\" International Association of Machinists' representative Lloyd Catlin said. \"There has been changes, but I don't know that it's enough.\"\n\nLund also said Boeing is working on ways to prevent door plugs from being closed if they are not firmly secured, but she could not say when that redesign might be completed.\n\nLater Tuesday, witnesses are expected to testify about the FAA's oversight of Boeing. FAA Administrator Mike Whitaker has conceded that his agency's oversight of the company \"was too hands-off -- too focused on paperwork audits and not focused enough on inspections.\" He has said that is changing.\n\nThe plane involved had been delivered to Alaska Airlines in late October and had made only about 150 flights. The airline stopped using the plane on flights to Hawaii after a warning light indicating a possible pressurization problem lit up on three different flights.\n\nNo one from the airline was called to testify this week before the NTSB. John Goglia, a former NTSB member, said that indicates the agency has determined \"that Alaska has no dirty hands in this.\"", "source": {"uri": "ctvnews.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CTV News"}, {"uri": "2024-08-446055111", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "18:21:53", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T18:21:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T18:07:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/hearing-seeks-insight-into-blowout-on-a-boeing-jet-that-pilots-said-threw-the-flight/article_34834293-5b30-5ce1-81f4-cd383ac8bd99.html", "title": "Hearing seeks insight into blowout on a Boeing jet that pilots said threw the flight into 'chaos'", "body": "FILE - The door plug from the Alaska Airlines Flight 1282's Boeing 737-9 MAX airplane is shown at the National Transportation Safety Board laboratory, in Washington, July 30, 2024. On Tuesday, August 6, 2024, the National Transportation Safety Board opens a two-day hearing on the blowout of the door plug from the Alaska Airlines flight traveling 16,000 feet above Oregon.\n\nThe midflight blowout of a panel from a Boeing 737 Max jet was so powerful that it blew open the plane's cockpit door and tore off the co-pilot's headset, and federal investigators began questioning officials from Boeing and its key supplier on Tuesday to understand how the accident occurred.\n\n\"It was chaos,\" the co-pilot of that Alaska Airlines flight on Jan. 5 flight said in documents released by the National Transportation Safety Board.\n\nComments of the pilots, factory workers at Boeing and other people were released as the safety board held a rare investigative hearing into the blowout, an accident that further tarnished Boeing's safety reputation and left it facing new legal jeopardy.\n\nThe National Transportation Safety Board's two-day hearing, which began Tuesday, could provide new insight into accident that caused a loud boom and left a gaping hole in the side of the Alaska Airlines jet. The NTSB also released more than 3,000 pages of documents with details about the incident.\n\nThe captain described \"an explosive experience\" and said he couldn't communicate with flight attendants, according to the documents. On the intercom, he heard flight attendants talking about a hole in the plane. He decided to land the plane as quickly as possible.\n\nThe pilots landed safely back in Portland. The door plug was found in a high school science teacher's backyard in Cedar Hills, Oregon.\n\nThe accident on flight 1282 occurred minutes after takeoff from Portland, Oregon, as the plane flew at 16,000 feet (4,800 meters). Oxygen masks dropped during the rapid decompression, a few cell phones and other objects were swept through the hole in the plane, passengers were terrified by wind and roaring noise, but miraculously there were no major injuries.\n\n\"This was quite traumatic to the crew and passengers,\" NTSB Chair Jennifer Homendy said as Tuesday's hearing began, speaking to anyone who may have been on the flight or knew someone aboard. \"We are so sorry for all that you experienced during this very traumatic event.\"\n\nHomendy said seven passengers and one flight attendant received minor physical injuries.\n\nThe NTSB said in a preliminary report that four bolts that help secure the panel, which is call a door plug, were not replaced after a repair job in a Boeing factory, but the company has said the work was not documented. During the hearing, safety board members are expected to question Boeing officials about the lack of paperwork that might have explained how such a potentially tragic mistake occurred.\n\nThe safety board will not determine a probable cause after the hearing. That could take another year or longer. It is calling the unusually long hearing a \"fact-finding\" step.\n\nBoeing supplier Spirit AeroSystems installed the door plug, a panel on many 737s that fills a cutout left for an extra exit required on some planes. The plug on the Alaska Airlines jet was removed and the bolts taken off in a Boeing factory to repair rivets.\n\nAmong the first witnesses called Tuesday was Elizabeth Lund, who has served as Boeing's senior vice president of quality -- a new position -- since February.\n\nWitnesses for Spirit and Boeing testified about safety systems and inspection processes. Lund said production of Max jets dropped below 10 per month after the Alaska Airlines blowout and has increased, but remains under 30 per month.\n\nLund and others also discussed the impact of COVID-19 on production and worker experience. Spirit Senior Vice President Terry George said that just five years ago, 95% of its factory employees had worked with sheet metal, but now it is 5%, and they must get more training in drilling holes and installing fasteners in aircraft bodies.\n\nBefore the pandemic, Lund added, most new hires at Boeing factories had aerospace experience, often in the military, but \"coming out of COVID ... we found that considerably more of our employees did not have that aerospace experience.\" She said the company has improved training since the January accident.\n\nBut others remained skeptical. \"We have never been impressed with Boeing's training at all,\" International Association of Machinists' representative Lloyd Catlin said. \"There has been changes, but I don't know that it's enough.\"\n\nLund also said Boeing is working on ways to prevent door plugs from being closed if they are not firmly secured, but she could not say when that redesign might be completed.\n\nLater Tuesday, witnesses are expected to testify about the FAA's oversight of Boeing. FAA Administrator Mike Whitaker has conceded that his agency's oversight of the company \"was too hands-off -- too focused on paperwork audits and not focused enough on inspections.\" He has said that is changing.\n\nThe plane involved had been delivered to Alaska Airlines in late October and had made only about 150 flights. The airline stopped using the plane on flights to Hawaii after a warning light indicating a possible pressurization problem lit up on three different flights.\n\nNo one from the airline was called to testify this week before the NTSB. John Goglia, a former NTSB member, said that indicates the agency has determined \"that Alaska has no dirty hands in this.\"", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8262559237", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "22:54:52", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T22:54:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T22:54:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.bendbulletin.com/localstate/state/hearing-seeks-insight-into-blowout-on-a-boeing-jet/article_c192b538-c44d-50f0-9a36-c4ef44f689b6.html", "title": "Hearing seeks insight into blowout on a Boeing jet", "body": "The top section of the door plug from the Alaska Airlines Flight 1282's Boeing 737-9 Max airplane is shown at the National Transportation Safety Board laboratory, in Washington, on July 31. The door plug is showing damaged bolts on the top right corner.\n\nThe midflight blowout of a panel from a Boeing 737 Max jet over Portland was so powerful that it blew open the plane's cockpit door and tore off the co-pilot's headset.\n\nFederal investigators began questioning officials from Boeing and its key supplier on Tuesday to understand how the accident occurred.\n\n\"It was chaos,\" the co-pilot of that Alaska Airlines flight on Jan. 5 flight said in documents released by the National Transportation Safety Board.\n\nComments of the pilots, factory workers at Boeing and other people were released as the safety board held a rare investigative hearing into the blowout, an accident that further tarnished Boeing's safety reputation and left it facing new legal jeopardy.\n\nThe National Transportation Safety Board's two-day hearing, which began Tuesday, could provide new insight into accident that caused a loud boom and left a gaping hole in the side of the Alaska Airlines jet. The NTSB also released more than 3,000 pages of documents with details about the incident.\n\nThe captain described \"an explosive experience\" and said he couldn't communicate with flight attendants, according to the documents. On the intercom, he heard flight attendants talking about a hole in the plane. He decided to land the plane as quickly as possible.\n\nThe pilots landed safely back at Portland International Airport. The door plug was found in a high school science teacher's backyard in Cedar Hills, just outside Portland.\n\nThe accident on Flight 1282 occurred minutes after takeoff from Portland as the plane flew at 16,000 feet. Oxygen masks dropped during the rapid decompression, a few cellphones and other objects were swept through the hole in the plane, passengers were terrified by wind and roaring noise, but miraculously there were no major injuries.\n\n\"This was quite traumatic to the crew and passengers,\" NTSB Chair Jennifer Homendy said as Tuesday's hearing began, speaking to anyone who may have been on the flight or knew someone aboard. \"We are so sorry for all that you experienced during this very traumatic event.\"\n\nHomendy said seven passengers and one flight attendant received minor physical injuries.\n\nThe NTSB said in a preliminary report that four bolts that help secure the panel, which is call a door plug, were not replaced after a repair job in a Boeing factory, but the company has said the work was not documented. During the hearing, safety board members are expected to question Boeing officials about the lack of paperwork that might have explained how such a potentially tragic mistake occurred.\n\nIntro subscription only $1.99\n\nThe safety board will not determine a probable cause after the hearing. That could take another year or longer. It is calling the unusually long hearing a \"fact-finding\" step.\n\nBoeing supplier Spirit AeroSystems installed the door plug, a panel on many 737s that fills a cutout left for an extra exit required on some planes. The plug on the Alaska Airlines jet was removed and the bolts taken off in a Boeing factory to repair rivets.\n\nAmong the first witnesses called Tuesday was Elizabeth Lund, who has served as Boeing's senior vice president of quality -- a new position -- since February.\n\nWitnesses for Spirit and Boeing testified about safety systems and inspection processes. Lund said production of Max jets dropped below 10 per month after the Alaska Airlines blowout and has increased, but remains under 30 per month.\n\nLund and others also discussed the impact of COVID-19 on production and worker experience. Spirit Senior Vice President Terry George said that just five years ago, 95% of its factory employees had worked with sheet metal, but now it is 5%, and they must get more training in drilling holes and installing fasteners in aircraft bodies.\n\nBefore the pandemic, Lund added, most new hires at Boeing factories had aerospace experience, often in the military, but \"coming out of COVID ... we found that considerably more of our employees did not have that aerospace experience.\" She said the company has improved training since the January accident.\n\nBut others remained skeptical. \"We have never been impressed with Boeing's training at all,\" International Association of Machinists' representative Lloyd Catlin said. \"There has been changes, but I don't know that it's enough.\"\n\nLund also said Boeing is working on ways to prevent door plugs from being closed if they are not firmly secured, but she could not say when that redesign might be completed.\n\nLater Tuesday, witnesses were expected to testify about the FAA's oversight of Boeing. FAA Administrator Mike Whitaker has conceded that his agency's oversight of the company \"was too hands-off -- too focused on paperwork audits and not focused enough on inspections.\" He has said that is changing.\n\nThe plane involved had been delivered to Alaska Airlines in late October and had made only about 150 flights. The airline stopped using the plane on flights to Hawaii after a warning light indicating a possible pressurization problem lit up on three different flights.\n\nNo one from the airline was called to testify this week before the NTSB. John Goglia, a former NTSB member, said that indicates the agency has determined \"that Alaska has no dirty hands in this.\"\n\nIntro subscription only $1.99 Our journalism needs your support. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9793139", "eventUri": "eng-9793139", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-07-31", "textStart": 181, "textEnd": 188}, {"uri": "8261962946", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "14:19:24", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T14:19:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T14:17:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://conservativeangle.com/boeing-to-testify-before-ntsb-on-alaska-airlines-door-plug-blowout/", "title": "Boeing to testify before NTSB on Alaska Airlines door plug blowout - Conservative Angle", "body": "(NewsNation) -- The National Transportation Safety Board will hold an investigative hearing Tuesday in Washington, D.C., on the Jan. 5 Alaska Airlines midflight door plug blowout.\n\nThe hearing is expected to be the most comprehensive analysis of why the door plug separated and blew off the Boeing 737 Max aircraft at 16,000 feet in the sky.\n\nThe accident further tarnished Boeing's safety reputation and left it facing new legal jeopardy.\n\nThe two-day hearing could provide new insight into the Jan. 5 accident, which caused a loud boom and left a gaping hole in the side of the Alaska Airlines jet.\n\nThe NTSB has said in a preliminary report that four bolts that help secure the panel, which covers a hole where an emergency exit door can be placed, were not replaced after a repair job in a Boeing factory. However, the company has said the work was not documented.\n\nDuring the two-day hearing, NTSB members are expected to question Boeing officials about the lack of paperwork that might have explained how such a potentially tragic mistake occurred. Board members are also expected to hear testimony from the company that manufactured the door plug, Spirit AeroSystems.\n\nTestimony is also expected from the International Association of Machinists and the Federal Aviation Administration.\n\nTuesday's hearing will focus on the production of Boeing 737 Max 9 planes and aircraft inspections.\n\nThe safety board will not determine a probable cause after the hearing. That could take another year or longer. It is calling the unusually long hearing a fact-finding step.\n\nThe goal of the two-day hearing will be for the NTSB to complete its investigation and later make safety recommendations.\n\nThe incident occurred minutes after takeoff from Portland, Oregon, as the plane flew at 16,000 feet. Oxygen masks dropped during the rapid decompression and a few cellphones and other objects were swept through the hole in the plane. Passengers were terrified by the wind and roaring noise.\n\nDespite a loss of pressure in the cabin, none of the 171 passengers or six crew members died, and the plane landed safely back in Portland. Only eight people on the aircraft reported minor injuries.\n\nThe door plug was found in a high school science teacher's backyard in Cedar Hills, Oregon.\n\nNo one from the airline was called to testify this week before the NTSB. John Goglia, a former NTSB member, said that indicates the agency has determined \"that Alaska has no dirty hands in this.\"\n\nThe plane involved had been delivered to Alaska Airlines in late October and had made only about 150 flights. Shortly before the door panel blowout, the airline had stopped using the plane on flights to Hawaii after a warning light indicating a possible pressurization problem lit up on three different flights.\n\nThe accident led to several investigations of Boeing, most of which are still underway.\n\nBoeing has faced much scrutiny following the door plug incident, and the company has promised to improve its safety culture, including increasing inspections and improving employee training.\n\nTension remains high between the NTSB and Boeing. Two months after the accident, NTSB Chair Jennifer Homendy and Boeing got into a public argument over whether the company was cooperating with investigators.\n\nAlso, effective this week, Boeing announced its new CEO Robert \"Kelly\" Ortberg will replace former CEO Dave Calhoun.\n\nEarlier this year, Calhoun faced pushback from lawmakers on Capitol Hill, with some accusing him of putting profits over safety.\n\nOrtberg will be the company's third chief executive in four and a half years.\n\nThe FBI has told passengers on the Alaska Airlines flight that they might be victims of a crime. The Justice Department pushed Boeing to plead guilty to a charge of conspiracy to commit fraud after finding that it failed to live up to a previous settlement related to regulatory approval of the Max.\n\nBoeing, which has yet to recover financially from two deadly crashes of Max jets in 2018 and 2019, has lost more than $25 billion since the start of 2019.\n\nBoeing also reported a $1.4 billion loss in revenue during its second quarter this year, which is around 10 times the loss it reported the same time last year.", "source": {"uri": "conservativeangle.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-08-446073714", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "18:48:57", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T18:48:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T21:38:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.trentonian.com/2024/08/05/hearing-seeks-insight-into-blowout-on-a-boeing-jet-that-pilots-said-threw-the-flight-into-chaos/", "title": "Hearing seeks insight into blowout on a Boeing jet that pilots said threw the flight into 'chaos'", "body": "The midflight blowout of a panel from a Boeing 737 Max jet was so powerful that it blew open the plane's cockpit door and tore off the co-pilot's headset, and federal investigators began questioning officials from Boeing and its key supplier on Tuesday to understand how the accident occurred.\n\n\"It was chaos,\" the co-pilot of that Alaska Airlines flight on Jan. 5 flight said in documents released by the National Transportation Safety Board.\n\nComments of the pilots, factory workers at Boeing and other people were released as the safety board held a rare investigative hearing into the blowout, an accident that further tarnished Boeing's safety reputation and left it facing new legal jeopardy.\n\nThe National Transportation Safety Board's two-day hearing, which began Tuesday, could provide new insight into accident that caused a loud boom and left a gaping hole in the side of the Alaska Airlines jet. The NTSB also released more than 3,000 pages of documents with details about the incident.\n\nThe captain described \"an explosive experience\" and said he couldn't communicate with flight attendants, according to the documents. On the intercom, he heard flight attendants talking about a hole in the plane. He decided to land the plane as quickly as possible.\n\nThe pilots landed safely back in Portland. The door plug was found in a high school science teacher's backyard in Cedar Hills, Oregon.\n\nThe accident on flight 1282 occurred minutes after takeoff from Portland, Oregon, as the plane flew at 16,000 feet (4,800 meters). Oxygen masks dropped during the rapid decompression, a few cell phones and other objects were swept through the hole in the plane, passengers were terrified by wind and roaring noise, but miraculously there were no major injuries.\n\n\"This was quite traumatic to the crew and passengers,\" NTSB Chair Jennifer Homendy said as Tuesday's hearing began, speaking to anyone who may have been on the flight or knew someone aboard. \"We are so sorry for all that you experienced during this very traumatic event.\"\n\nHomendy said seven passengers and one flight attendant received minor physical injuries.\n\nThe NTSB said in a preliminary report that four bolts that help secure the panel, which is call a door plug, were not replaced after a repair job in a Boeing factory, but the company has said the work was not documented. During the hearing, safety board members are expected to question Boeing officials about the lack of paperwork that might have explained how such a potentially tragic mistake occurred.\n\nThe safety board will not determine a probable cause after the hearing. That could take another year or longer. It is calling the unusually long hearing a \"fact-finding\" step.\n\nBoeing supplier Spirit AeroSystems installed the door plug, a panel on many 737s that fills a cutout left for an extra exit required on some planes. The plug on the Alaska Airlines jet was removed and the bolts taken off in a Boeing factory to repair rivets.\n\nAmong the first witnesses called Tuesday was Elizabeth Lund, who has served as Boeing's senior vice president of quality -- a new position -- since February.\n\nWitnesses for Spirit and Boeing testified about safety systems and inspection processes. Lund said production of Max jets dropped below 10 per month after the Alaska Airlines blowout and has increased, but remains under 30 per month.\n\nLund and others also discussed the impact of COVID-19 on production and worker experience. Spirit Senior Vice President Terry George said that just five years ago, 95% of its factory employees had worked with sheet metal, but now it is 5%, and they must get more training in drilling holes and installing fasteners in aircraft bodies.\n\nBefore the pandemic, Lund added, most new hires at Boeing factories had aerospace experience, often in the military, but \"coming out of COVID ... we found that considerably more of our employees did not have that aerospace experience.\" She said the company has improved training since the January accident.\n\nBut others remained skeptical. \"We have never been impressed with Boeing's training at all,\" International Association of Machinists' representative Lloyd Catlin said. \"There has been changes, but I don't know that it's enough.\"\n\nLund also said Boeing is working on ways to prevent door plugs from being closed if they are not firmly secured, but she could not say when that redesign might be completed.\n\nLater Tuesday, witnesses are expected to testify about the FAA's oversight of Boeing. FAA Administrator Mike Whitaker has conceded that his agency's oversight of the company \"was too hands-off -- too focused on paperwork audits and not focused enough on inspections.\" He has said that is changing.\n\nThe plane involved had been delivered to Alaska Airlines in late October and had made only about 150 flights. The airline stopped using the plane on flights to Hawaii after a warning light indicating a possible pressurization problem lit up on three different flights.\n\nNo one from the airline was called to testify this week before the NTSB. John Goglia, a former NTSB member, said that indicates the agency has determined \"that Alaska has no dirty hands in this.\"", "source": {"uri": "trentonian.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The {"uri": "8262242410", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "17:43:57", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T17:43:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T17:42:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/business/aerospace/hearing-before-ntsb-delves-into-boeing-737-max-panel-blowout/article_936fc134-5417-11ef-bfc9-137e30e9f2f3.html", "title": "Hearing before NTSB delves into Boeing 737 Max panel blowout", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Investigators are questioning Boeing Co. officials in hearings this week about the midflight blowout of a panel from a 737 Max, an accident that further tarnished the planemaker's safety reputation and left it facing new legal jeopardy.\n\nThe National Transportation Safety Board's two-day hearing, which began Aug. 6, could provide new insight into the Jan. 5 accident that caused a loud boom and left a gaping hole in the side of the Alaska Airlines jet.\n\n\"This was quite traumatic to the crew and passengers,\" NTSB chair Jennifer Homendy said as the hearing began Tuesday, speaking to anyone who may have been on the flight or knew someone aboard. \"We are so sorry for all that you experienced during this very traumatic event.\"\n\nThe NTSB said in a preliminary report that four bolts that help secure the panel, which is called a door plug, were not replaced after a repair job in a Boeing factory, but the company has said the work was not documented. During the hearing, safety board members are expected to question Boeing officials about the lack of paperwork that might have explained how such a potentially tragic mistake occurred.\n\n\"The NTSB wants to fill in the gaps of what is known about this incident and to put people on the record about it,\" said John Goglia, a former NTSB member. The agency will be looking to underscore Boeing's failures in following the process it had told the Federal Aviation Administration it was going to use in such cases, he said.\n\nThe safety board will not determine a probable cause after the hearing. That could take another year or longer. It is calling the unusually long hearing a \"fact-finding\" step.\n\nThe first witnesses called Tuesday included Elizabeth Lund, Boeing's senior vice president of quality -- a new position -- since February.\n\nBoeing supplier Spirit AeroSystems installed the door plug, a panel on many 737s that fills a cutout left for an extra exit required on some planes. The plug on the Alaska Airlines jet was removed and the bolts taken off in a Boeing factory to repair rivets.\n\nWitnesses for Spirit and Boeing testified about safety systems and inspection processes. Lund said production of Max jets dropped below 10 per month after the Alaska Airlines blowout and has increased. but remains under 30 per month.\n\nWitnesses are expected to testify about the opening and closing of the door plug and the FAA's oversight of Boeing.\n\nFAA chief Mike Whitaker has conceded that his agency's oversight of the company \"was too hands-off -- too focused on paperwork audits and not focused enough on inspections.\" He has said that is changing.\n\nThe plane involved had been delivered to Alaska Airlines in late October and had made only about 150 flights. The airline stopped using the plane on flights to Hawaii after a warning light indicating a possible pressurization problem lit up on three different flights.\n\nToday's Top Headlines\n\nStory continues below\n\nHow a former SC mill town is becoming a hot spot for thrill seekers and nature enthusiasts Live updates: Charleston extends curfew as Tropical Storm Debby brings heavy rain, reported tornadoes 2 principals resign after back-to-school photos showing SC teachers as Border Patrol agents These Myrtle Beach radio hosts were on the air for decades. They lost their jobs last week. Aiken resident's search for Amelia Earhart featured in Discovery Channel documentary Tropical Storm Debby begins slow spin into South Carolina. Curfew set in Charleston. Sen. Tim Scott weds Mindy Noce in Seacoast Church service: 'You've made me the happiest man alive' SC has seen 20 inches of rain before. What can that tell us about Debby's potential impacts? Debby takes Charleston travelers by storm as airlines cancel and delay flights Charleston island leaders warn visitors the beaches may look different after Tropical Storm Debby\n\nThe accident on flight 1282 occurred minutes after takeoff from Portland, Ore., as the plane flew at 16,000 feet. Oxygen masks dropped during the rapid decompression, a few wireless phones and other objects were swept through the hole in the plane, passengers were terrified by wind and roaring noise, but miraculously there were no major injuries. Homendy said Tuesday that seven passengers and one flight attendant received minor physical injuries.\n\nThe pilots landed safely back in Portland. The door plug was found in a high school science teacher's back yard in Cedar Hills, Ore.\n\nNo one from the airline was called to testify this week before the NTSB. Goglia, the former safety board member, said that indicates the agency has determined \"that Alaska has no dirty hands in this.\"\n\nTension remains high between the NTSB and Boeing, however. Two months after the accident, Homendy and the Arlington, Va.-based company got into a public argument over whether the company was cooperating with investigators.\n\nThat spat was largely smoothed over, but in June a Boeing executive angered the board by discussing the investigation with reporters and -- even worse in the agency's view -- suggesting that the NTSB was interested in finding someone to blame for the blowout.\n\nNTSB officials see their role as identifying the cause of accidents to prevent similar ones in the future. They are not prosecutors, and they fear that witnesses won't come forward if they think NTSB is looking for culprits.\n\nSo the NTSB issued a subpoena for Boeing representatives while stripping the company of its customary right to ask questions during the hearing.\n\nThe accident led to several investigations of Boeing, most of which are still underway.\n\nThe FBI has told passengers on the Alaska Airlines flight that they might be victims of a crime. The Justice Department pushed Boeing to plead guilty to a charge of conspiracy to commit fraud after finding that it failed to live up to a previous settlement related to regulatory approval of the Max.\n\nBoeing, which has yet to recover financially from two deadly crashes of Max jets in 2018 and 2019, has lost more than $25 billion since the start of 2019. Later this week, the company will get its third chief executive in 4\u00bd years when Kelly Ortberg replaces the retiring Dave Calhoun.\n\nTestimony from NTSB hearings is not admissible in court, but lawyers suing Boeing over this and other accidents will be watching, knowing that they can seek depositions from witnesses to cover the same ground.\n\n\"Our cases are already solid -- door plugs shouldn't blow out during a flight,\" said one of those lawyers, Mark Lindquist of Seattle. \"Our cases grow even stronger, however, if the blowout was the result of habitually shoddy practices. Are jurors going to see this as negligence or something worse?\"\n\nSign up for our business newsletter. Our twice-weekly newsletter features all the business stories shaping Charleston and South Carolina. "name": "David Koenig", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alaska_Airlines", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Alaska Airlines"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Boeing"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Transportation_Safety_Board", "type": "wiki", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9793139", "eventUri": "eng-9793139", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Washington (state)"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-08-06", "textStart": 324, "textEnd": 330}, {"amb": false, "date": "-01-05", "textStart": 367, "textEnd": 373}], "sentiment": -0.2392156862745098, "wgt": 215, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8261091468", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "04:18:03", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T04:18:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T04:17:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://heraldcourier.com/news/state-and-regional/witnesses-will-tell-a-federal-safety-board-about-the-blowout-on-a-boeing-737-max/article_43d5e0a7-f15e-5e0b-bf2c-2c2631df6dd1.html", "title": "Witnesses will tell a federal safety board about the blowout on a Boeing 737 Max earlier this year", "body": "By DAVID KOENIG - AP Airlines Writer\n\nInvestigators will question Boeing officials during a hearing starting Tuesday about the midflight blowout of a panel from a 737 Max, an accident that further tarnished the company's safety reputation and left it facing new legal jeopardy.\n\nThe two-day hearing could provide new insight into the Jan. 5 accident, which caused a loud boom and left a gaping hole in the side of the Alaska Airlines jet.\n\nThe National Transportation Safety Board has said in a preliminary report that four bolts that help secure the panel, which is call a door plug, were not replaced after a repair job in a Boeing factory, but the company has said the work was not documented. During the two-day hearing, safety board members are expected to question Boeing officials about the lack of paperwork that might have explained how such a potentially tragic mistake occurred.\n\nPeople are also reading... VHSL PRESEASON FOOTBALL PRIMER: Plenty of storylines as prep football begins in Virginia HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Not yet 30, Norris achieves goal as Lebanon head coach Antiques showcased at Virginia Highlands Festival HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL | Trust and obey: Former Sullivan East star Laisure now playing for Science Hill Hilltoppers PREP BASKETBALL: Field released for The Classic at Tennessee High Platter & Pour working to open State Street location OLYMPICS: Johnson City-born Brody Malone helps U.S. get bronze in men's gymnastics team competition HIGH SCHOOL NOTEBOOK: Wise Central's Emmah McAmis on Under Armour national title team; Some transfers and new coaching hires as well LOCAL MOTORSPORTS: Chilhowie racer knows the Bristol Motor Speedway experience Harshbarger defeats Lundberg in heated state senate race PREP SPORTS: VHSL leaders hold public meeting in Abingdon HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL: Hart steps down at Honaker, not seeing commitment in offseason The Big Tri City Fair looks to bring fun and entertainment HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Viking football just means more to Tennessee High's Trent Dowdell MLB: Rangers outfielder Evan Carter (Elizabethton) likely to miss rest of regular season with back injury\n\n\"The NTSB wants to fill in the gaps of what is known about this incident and to put people on the record about it,\" said John Goglia, a former NTSB member. The agency will be looking to underscore Boeing's failures in following the process it had told the Federal Aviation Administration it was going to use in such cases, he said.\n\nThe safety board will not determine a probable cause after the hearing. That could take another year or longer. It is calling the unusually long hearing a fact-finding step.\n\nAmong the scheduled witnesses is Elizabeth Lund, who has been Boeing's senior vice president of quality -- a new position -- since February, and officials from Spirit AeroSystems, which makes fuselages for Max jets.\n\nSpirit installed the door plug -- a panel that fills a space created for an extra exit on some planes -- on the Alaska Airlines jet, but the panel was removed and the bolts taken off in a Boeing factory near Seattle to repair rivets.\n\nThe NTSB's agenda for the hearing includes testimony about manufacturing and inspections, the opening and closing of the door plug in the Boeing factory, safety systems at Boeing and Spirit, and the FAA's supervision of Boeing.\n\nFAA Administrator Mike Whitaker has conceded that his agency's oversight of the company \"was too hands-off -- too focused on paperwork audits and not focused enough on inspections.\" He has said that is changing.\n\nThe plane involved had been delivered to Alaska Airlines in late October and had made only about 150 flights. The airline stopped using the plane on flights to Hawaii after a warning light indicating a possible pressurization problem lit up on three different flights.\n\nThe accident on flight 1282 occurred minutes after takeoff from Portland, Oregon, as the plane flew at 16,000 feet (4,800 meters). Oxygen masks dropped during the rapid decompression, a few cell phones and other objects were swept through the hole in the plane, passengers were terrified by wind and roaring noise, but miraculously no one was injured.\n\nThe pilots landed safely back in Portland. The door plug was found in a high school science teacher's backyard in Cedar Hills, Oregon.\n\nNo one from the airline was called to testify this week before the NTSB. Goglia, the former safety board member, said that indicates the agency has determined \"that Alaska has no dirty hands in this.\"\n\nTension remains high between the NTSB and Boeing, however. Two months after the accident, board Chair Jennifer Homendy and Boeing got into a public argument over whether the company was cooperating with investigators.\n\nThat spat was largely smoothed over, but in June a Boeing executive angered the board by discussing the investigation with reporters and -- even worse in the agency's view -- suggesting that the NTSB was interested in finding someone to blame for the blowout.\n\nNTSB officials see their role as identifying the cause of accidents to prevent similar ones in the future. They are not prosecutors, and they fear that witnesses won't come forward if they think NTSB is looking for culprits.\n\nSo the NTSB issued a subpoena for Boeing representatives while stripping the company of its customary right to ask questions during the hearing.\n\nThe accident led to several investigations of Boeing, most of which are still underway.\n\nThe FBI has told passengers on the Alaska Airlines flight that they might be victims of a crime. The Justice Department pushed Boeing to plead guilty to a charge of conspiracy to commit fraud after finding that it failed to live up to a previous settlement related to regulatory approval of the Max.\n\nBoeing, which has yet to recover financially from two deadly crashes of Max jets in 2018 and 2019, has lost more than $25 billion since the start of 2019. Later this week, the company will get its third chief executive in 4 1/2 years.\n\nTestimony from NTSB hearings is not admissible in court, but lawyers suing Boeing over this and other accidents will be watching, knowing that they can seek depositions from witnesses to cover the same ground.\n\n\"Our cases are already solid -- door plugs shouldn't blow out during a flight,\" said one of those lawyers, Mark Lindquist of Seattle. \"Our cases grow even stronger, however, if the blowout was the result of habitually shoddy practices. Are jurors going to see this as negligence or something worse?\"\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed without permission.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree {"uri": "8261080914", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "04:09:04", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T04:09:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T04:07:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://gulfnews.com/business/aviation/hearing-to-probe-alaska-airlines-emergency-on-boeing-jet-1.1722915886118", "title": "Hearing to probe Alaska Airlines emergency on Boeing jet", "body": "New York: US investigators will on Tuesday open a two-day hearing into a near-catastrophic January incident on a Boeing 737 MAX operated by Alaska Airlines that required an emergency landing.\n\nVideo of the episode showed oxygen masks hanging in front of a gaping airplane space from a panel that blew out shortly after takeoff, leaving passengers exposed to open air at an altitude of about 16,000 feet.\n\nThe hearing in Washington aims \"to determine the facts, circumstances, and probable cause of the transportation accident... and to make recommendations to improve transportation safety,\" said the National Transportation Safety Board, which is overseeing the probe.\n\nread more Alaska Air says Boeing paid it $160 million in compensation for MAX 9 grounding Seat belt saved passenger's life on Alaska Air Boeing 737 jet that suffered a blowout, new lawsuit says Video: Alaska Air Boeing plane blows out window, fuselage after take-off Alaska Air blowout on 737 Max seen as likely caused by manufacturing issue\n\nThe plane soon went back to Portland where it safely landed, although there were eight minor injuries.\n\nThe NTSB immediately launched a probe and after a month said four bolts securing the panel were missing, according to preliminary findings released February 6.\n\nThe agency has collected written documents and photos showing that Boeing employees removed four bolts from these locations during an inspection at the Renton plant in Washington state prior to delivery of the aircraft last October.\n\nOver the course of two day-long sessions on Tuesday and Wednesday in Washington, the NTSB will hear from about 15 witnesses.\n\nSpeakers include Elizabeth Lund, senior vice president for quality at Boeing, among other officials at the company, as well as officials from key supplier Spirit AeroSystems, regulator Federal Aviation Administration and the machinists union.\n\nThe witness list does not include Alaska Airlines.\n\nLund came under fire from the NTSB after providing a detailed summary of the incident in June to journalists touring the company's Renton plant.\n\nBoeing staff identified five \"non-conforming\" rivets in the fuselage after the arrived in Renton, but the issue \"did not create a safety hazard,\" Lund told reporters.\n\nBut when the fuselage panel, known as the door plug, was removed to replace the rivets, Boeing staff failed to file the documentation to make the change on the door plug, Lund said.\n\n\"We believe that plug was opened without the correct paperwork,\" Lund told reporters. \"There was a non-compliance to our processes at that point.\"\n\nShe also said Boeing was focused on closing a \"gap\" over the lack of documentation and that determining who did the work \"is the responsibility of the NTSB and that investigation is still going on.\"\n\nBoeing sanctioned\n\nAfter Lund's comments were published in June, the NTSB announced it was sanctioning the company for sharing details about an ongoing probe that were not supposed to be discussed publicly.\n\nLund \"released non-public investigative information and made unsubstantiated speculations about possible causes of the Jan. 5 door-plug blowout, which is directly at issue in the ongoing investigation,\" the NTSB said in a June 27 letter to Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun.\n\nSome of the information \"was either inaccurate or unknown to the NTSB,\" the letter added. \"This disregard of the federal regulations and rules governing NTSB investigations cannot be tolerated.\"\n\nAs a result, the NTSB said it is blocking Boeing from reviewing information gathered in its investigation and will not permit the company to ask questions of other witnesses at the hearing.\n\nNTSB Chair Jennifer Homendy in March had also sharply criticized Boeing's handling of the probe, telling a congressional hearing the company was dragging its feet in providing key documentation and witnesses involved in working on the plane.\n\nTuesday's hearing comes as Boeing faces heavy scrutiny from regulators following the January incident and in the wake of congressional testimony from whistleblowers who say the company punishes workers who raise safety issues while moving to cover up problems.", "source": {"uri": "gulfnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "GULF {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dave_Calhoun", "type": "person", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Dave Calhoun"}}, {"uri": "https://imagevars.gulfnews.com/2024/03/15/Boeing_Jetliner_Blowout_Lawsuit_21037--4c195--Read-Only-_18e414d0059_medium.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9793139", "eventUri": "eng-9793139", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "-02-06", "textStart": 1266, "textEnd": 1276}, {"amb": false, "date": "-01-05", "textStart": 3107, "textEnd": 3113}, {"amb": {"uri": "8262358455", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "19:27:46", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T19:27:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T19:26:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://keyt.com/news/money-and-business/cnn-business-consumer/2024/08/06/cockroaches-of-the-factory-workers-paint-a-picture-of-chaos-and-dysfunction-at-boeing/", "title": "'Cockroaches of the factory': Workers paint a picture of chaos and dysfunction at Boeing", "body": "CNN, ELIZABETH, NTSB, SENATE HOMELAND SECURITY CMTE\n\nBy Chris Isidore and Pete Muntean, CNN\n\nWashington (CNN) -- Workers on the Boeing 737 Max that lost a door plug on a January flight told federal safety investigators that they felt pressure to do their jobs too fast to avoid mistakes, according to testimony released Tuesday at the start of a two-day investigative hearing.\n\nThe revelation came at the start of a two-day hearing Tuesday by the National Transportation Safety Board into the blowout, with investigators questioning Boeing personnel about safety issues at the planemaker and what that might mean for passengers on its ubiquitous planes.\n\nPreviously, the NTSB said the door plug ripped off in mid-flight because the plane left a Boeing factory without the four bolts needed to keep the door plug in place.\n\nMany of those documents were transcripts of interviews conducted by NTSB investigators during the seven months since the accident. One of those interviewed, identified only as \"Assembler Installer Doors B,\" told the investigator that the workload at the Boeing factory was too great to avoid mistakes from being made.\n\n\"As far as the workload, I feel like we were definitely trying to put out too much product, right?\" said the unidentified Boeing worker. \"That's how mistakes are made. People try to work too fast. I mean, I can't speak for anybody else, but we were busy. We were working a lot.\"\n\nOne transcript showed that a Boeing employee, identified as a Door Master Lead, told investigators there planes required much of the work during the assembly process to be redone because of problems that are discovered, as happened with the door plug that was removed to fix some rivets. The worker said there was no special training to open, close, or remove a door plug versus a regular door.\n\nThat worker told the NTSB that his team was \"put in uncharted waters to where... we were replacing doors like we were replacing our underwear.\"\n\n\"The planes come in jacked up every day. Every day,\" the second worker added.\n\nOne FAA inspector at the Boeing factory told NTSB investigators that FAA inspectors have \"heard of pressure, [but] haven't been able to substantiate those claims.\"\n\nThe fuselage of the plane was manufactured by Boeing supplier Spirit AeroSystems, and it arrived at the Boeing factory with the four bolts in place, according to testimony at the hearing. But there were problems with the rivets by the door plug that needed to be repaired, so the door plug was removed so the work could be done. There were Spirit employees at the Boeing plant, but communication between the Boeing and Spirit workers on the floor of the Boeing factory wasn't good, according to another interview transcript released Tuesday.\n\n\"Well, basically we're the cockroaches of the factory,\" one unidentified Spirit employee told NTSB investigators.\n\nAnd a Boeing team captain at the 737 factory told investigators of problems of low employee morale and high turnover.\n\n\"We have a lot of turnover specifically because, you know, this can be a stressful job, you know,\" the Boeing team captain is quoted as saying in one of the transcripts. \"What the company wants and what we have the skills and capabilities to perform at the time sometimes that doesn't coincide, and so some people get disgruntled; they feel like they're being overworked; they feel like, you know, that we might be getting taken advantage of.\"\n\nThe January 5 Alaska Airlines flight had the door plug blow out of the side of a Boeing 737 Max as it approached 16,000 feet. The incident left a gaping hole in the side of the plane, sending oxygen masks falling from the ceiling, tearing off clothing and ripping phones out of passengers' hands and hurling them into the darkness.\n\nFortunately, the crew was able to land the crippled jet without any serious physical injuries. There were seven passengers and one flight attendant treated for injuries upon landing. It was a combination of the skill of the flight crew and good luck that no one was killed.\n\nBut the trauma of being on the flight likely affected many of those aboard the plane, said Jennifer Homendy, the chair of the NTSB, in the opening comments of the hearing.\n\n\"Injuries we can't see, which we often don't talk about can have profound and lasting impacts on lives and livelihoods,\" she said. She offered an apology on behalf of the agency to the people on the flight.\n\nThe accident did serious damage to the public's confidence in plane manufacturer Boeing, prompting a series of federal investigations into its practices and the safety and quality of its aircraft.\n\nBoeing executives in charge of quality control are facing the safety board for questions, including Boeing Commercial Airplanes' senior vice president of quality Elizabeth Lund. Alongside Lund for half of Tuesday's hearing is Doug Ackerman, vice president of supplier quality for Boeing Commercial Airplanes.\n\nThe rare, two-day-long investigative hearing is key to closing the case on the January 5 incident, which led to a 19-day-long grounding of 737 MAX 9s in the United States. The NTSB says it will \"use the information gathered to complete the investigation, determine probable cause, and make recommendations to improve transportation safety.\"\n\nBut Homendy was clearly frustrated and ready to push back on Boeing in early testimony, telling Lund that \"this is not a PR campaign for Boeing.\" She said the hearing is being held to find out what was done ahead of the accident, not the tougher training and quality improvements made since then.\n\n\"You can talk about where we are today, but this is an investigation on what happened on January 5th,\" Homendy said.\n\nThe NTSB has already released preliminary findings from the incident, disclosing that the plane used on the flight left the Boeing factory in Renton, Washington, 10 weeks earlier and without the four bolts needed to hold the door plug in place.\n\nSince that report, Boeing has said the reasons for that oversight came down to something as simple as a lack of paperwork.\n\nWhen the fuselage of the plane arrived at the Boeing factory from supplier Spirit AeroSystems, the door plug was in place, as were the four bolts meant to hold it securely attached to the side of the jet. But there were problems with five rivets near where the door plug was installed, and Boeing workers removed the door plug in order to fix those rivets.\n\nAccording to Boeing, the workers who fixed the rivets didn't generate the paperwork indicating they had removed the door plug and the four bolts in order to do that work.\n\nWhen a different group of employees put the plug back in place, Boeing says the employees didn't think the plane would actually fly in that condition. Instead, they were just blocking the hole with the plug to protect the inside of the fuselage from weather as the plane moved outside to a different area of the factory compound. That group of employees often makes those kind of temporary fixes.\n\nThose employees likely assumed paperwork existed showing that the plug and bolts had been removed, and that paperwork would prompt someone else along the line to install the bolts. But without the paperwork, no one on the assembly line knew that the door plug had ever been removed, or that its bolts were missing and needed to be replaced.\n\nBut the probe is only one of the problems Boeing faces because of the incident.\n\nThere could be criminal charges related to the failures that led to the incident, as the FBI has notified passengers and crew members that they might be considered crime victims.\n\nEven before the flight, Boeing faced the possibility of criminal charges because of problems with the 737 Max that were kept hidden from the Federal Aviation Administration during the original certification process. Those problems led to a design flaw on the plane that is blamed for two fatal crashes in 2018 and 2019 that killed 346 people.\n\nIn January 2021, Boeing and the Justice Department agreed to a settlement that deferred criminal prosecution of Boeing for three years for its employees defrauding the FAA during the certification process. But that three-year probationary period had been due to end just days after the January 5 flight. Instead, the DOJ reopened the investigation following the Alaska Airlines incident, and last month Boeing agreed to plead guilty to criminal charges and be put under the supervision of a court-appointed monitor.\n\nThe FAA has also increased scrutiny of Boeing's manufacturing process and is limiting how many planes it can build, which has added to financial losses at the company that have now reached $33 billion since the second fatal crash in 2019.\n\nBoeing's sales have plunged 70% in the first six months of the this year. In June it sold just three passenger jets, and one of those was to Alaska Airlines to replace the plane used in the January 5 flight, which Boeing has repurchased from the airline.\n\nCNN's Owen Dahlkamp, Danya Gainor, Celina Tebor, Nicki Brown, Ramishah Maruf contributed to this report.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company.
