{"uri": "2024-08-445535616", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "10:11:47", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T10:11:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T10:00:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.cnn.com/2024/08/06/business/boeing-737-max-blowout-ntsb-hearings-day-one/index.html", "title": "We're about to get the most detailed explanation yet for Boeing's terrifying mid-air blowout | CNN Business", "body": "In this National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) handout, plastic covers the exterior of the fuselage plug area of Alaska Airlines Flight 1282 Boeing 737-9 MAX on January 7, 2024 in Portland, Oregon. A door-sized section near the rear of the Boeing 737-9 MAX plane blew off 10 minutes after Alaska Airlines Flight 1282 took off from Portland, Oregon on January 5 on its way to Ontario, California.\n\nCNN --\n\nThe public already knows a lot about the January 5 Alaska Airlines flight that had a door plug blow out of the side of a Boeing 737 Max as it approached 16,000 feet. On Tuesday, we could find out a lot more.\n\nThe incident left a gaping hole in the side of the plane, sending oxygen masks falling from the ceiling, tearing off clothing and ripping phones out of passengers' hands and hurling them into the darkness.\n\nFortunately, the crew was able to land the crippled jet without any serious injuries. It was a combination of the skill of the flight crew and good luck that no one was killed. The accident did do serious damage to the public's confidence in plane manufacturer Boeing, prompting a series of federal investigations into its practices and the safety and quality of its aircraft.\n\nOne of those investigations is being conducted by the National Transportation Safety Board, the federal regulator that investigates all manner of accidents, from railroad derailments to some car crashes to virtually all plane crashes.\n\nThe NTSB is scheduled to hold 20 hours of public hearings about the Alaska Airlines incident spread over two days, starting Tuesday morning. It will begin by making public a docket of more than 60 documents running more than 3,800 pages that have been collected in the seven months since the accident.\n\nBoeing executives in charge of quality control will then face the safety board for questions, including Boeing Commercial Airplanes' senior vice president of quality Elizabeth Lund, according to a new agenda posted by the NTSB. Alongside Lund for half of Tuesday's hearing will be Doug Ackerman, vice president of supplier quality for Boeing Commercial Airplanes.\n\nThe NTSB will ask how the Boeing 737 MAX 9 door plug was removed and reinstalled without critical bolts before the plane was delivered to Alaska Airlines. The NTSB will also ask about the \"lack of documentation\" on the factory floor, according to the agenda, as well as changes the manufacturing Goliath implemented after the incident.\n\nThe rare, two-day-long investigative hearing is key to closing the case on the January 5 incident, which led to a 19-day-long grounding of 737 MAX 9s in the United States. The NTSB says it will \"use the information gathered to complete the investigation, determine probable cause, and make recommendations to improve transportation safety.\"\n\nA final report is still months away.\n\nMissing bolts -- and missing paperwork\n\nThe NTSB has already released preliminary findings from the incident, disclosing that the plane used on the flight left the Boeing factory in Renton, Washington, 10 weeks earlier and without the four bolts needed to hold the door plug in place.\n\nSince that report, Boeing has said the reasons for that oversight came down to something as simple as a lack of paperwork.\n\nWhen the fuselage of the plane arrived at the Boeing factory from supplier Spirit AeroSystems, the door plug was in place, as were the four bolts meant to hold it securely attached to the side of the jet. But there were problems with five rivets near where the door plug was installed, and Boeing workers removed the door plug in order to fix those rivets.\n\nAccording to Boeing, the workers who fixed the rivets didn't generate the paperwork indicating they had removed the door plug and the four bolts in order to do that work.\n\nWhen a different group of employees put the plug back in place, Boeing says the employees didn't think the plane would actually fly in that condition. Instead, they were just blocking the hole with the plug to protect the inside of the fuselage from weather as the plane moved outside to a different area of the factory compound. That group of employees often makes those kind of temporary fixes.\n\nThose employees likely assumed paperwork existed showing that the plug and bolts had been removed, and that paperwork would prompt someone else along the line to install the bolts. But without the paperwork, no one on the assembly line knew that the door plug had ever been removed, or that its bolts were missing and needed to be replaced.\n\nTragedy narrowly averted\n\nThe fact that the door plug didn't come out when the plane was at 35,000 feet rather than at a lower altitude with passengers still buckled into their seats is the first part of the good luck.\n\nThe plane made 153 flights with passengers on it from the time it was delivered to Alaska Airlines in late October and the January 5 flight, including 22 flights that took it over the Pacific Ocean for hours flying to and from Hawaii. It would have had much more difficulty making it safely to the ground if the door plug had failed hours, rather than minutes, from the nearest runway.\n\nAnd the fact that the two seats immediately adjacent to the door plug were two of the only seven empty seats on the plane carrying 177 people was very important in preventing fatalities. The force of the air inside the cabin rushing through the hole was enough to twist and bend the metal seats themselves towards the opening. Would-be passengers sitting in those unoccupied seats might not have been able to stay in the the plane, especially if they were not buckled in.\n\nBut perhaps most fortunate of all, when the door plug came out, it fell away from the plane without hitting the tail section, perhaps damaging the the rudder or the vertical stabilizers on the tail, which are crucial to the plane flying straight, level and under control. If that had happened, it would have been very difficult for the plane to land safely, if at all.\n\nBoeing's mounting problems\n\nBut the probe is only one of the problems Boeing faces because of the incident.\n\nThere could be criminal charges related to the failures that led to the incident, as the FBI has notified passengers and crew members that they might be considered crime victims.\n\nEven before the flight, Boeing faced the possibility of criminal charges because of problems with the 737 Max that were kept hidden from the Federal Aviation Administration during the original certification process. Those problems led to a design flaw on the plane that is blamed for two fatal crashes in 2018 and 2019 that killed 346 people.\n\nIn January 2021, Boeing and the Justice Department agreed to a settlement that deferred criminal prosecution of Boeing for three years for its employees defrauding the FAA during the certification process. But that three-year probationary period had been due to end just days after the January 5 flight. Instead, the DOJ reopened the investigation following the Alaska Airlines incident, and last month Boeing agreed to plead guilty to criminal charges and be put under the supervision of a court-appointed monitor.\n\nThe FAA has also increased scrutiny of Boeing's manufacturing process and is limiting how many planes it can build, which has added to financial losses at the company that have now reached $33 billion since the second fatal crash in 2019.\n\nBoeing's sales have plunged 70% in the first six months of the this year. In June it sold just three passenger jets, and one of those was to Alaska Airlines to replace the plane used in the January 5 flight, which Boeing has repurchased from the airline.\n\nLast days of current leadership\n\nBoeing will get a new boss the day after the hearing ends on Wednesday, as Dave Calhoun, who has served as CEO since January 2020, steps down and Kelly Ortberg, the former CEO of aerospace supplier Rockwell Collins, assumes the top job.\n\nCalhoun's departure is being termed a retirement, and he is 67. But when Boeing's board waived the retirement age for top executives for Calhoun in 2021 so he didn't have to retire after two years on the job, he said he intended to stay \"as long as they want me.\" He could have stayed in the job through 2027 under the waiver granted in 2021.\n\nHe has faced harsh criticism for many of Boeing's problems, with more than a dozen whistleblowers at the company complaining to congressional investigators that they faced pressure and retaliation for flagging safety problems in the company's assembly process.\n\nCalhoun has only testified on Capitol Hill once despite all the attention Boeing has received. In a stunning understatement he conceded the company's safety culture was \"far from perfect,\" but vowed that safety is a priority and that the company is making progress. But that didn't stop a bipartisan grilling at a Senate hearing in June.\n\n\"Why haven't you resigned?,\" he was asked by Senator Josh Hawley during that hearing.\n\n\"Senator, I'm sticking this through,\" he replied. But his plans to leave the company by the end of the year had already been announced by the time of the hearing.", "source": {"uri": "cnn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CNN"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8261655595", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "11:07:03", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T11:07:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T11:03:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://kion546.com/money/cnn-business-consumer/2024/08/06/were-about-to-get-the-most-detailed-explanation-yet-for-boeings-terrifying-mid-air-blowout-3/", "title": "We're about to get the most detailed explanation yet for Boeing's terrifying mid-air blowout - KION546", "body": "(CNN) -- The public already knows a lot about the January 5 Alaska Airlines flight that had a door plug blow out of the side of a Boeing 737 Max as it approached 16,000 feet. On Tuesday, we could find out a lot more.\n\nThe incident left a gaping hole in the side of the plane, sending oxygen masks falling from the ceiling, tearing off clothing and ripping phones out of passengers' hands and hurling them into the darkness.\n\nFortunately, the crew was able to land the crippled jet without any serious injuries. It was a combination of the skill of the flight crew and good luck that no one was killed. The accident did do serious damage to the public's confidence in plane manufacturer Boeing, prompting a series of federal investigations into its practices and the safety and quality of its aircraft.\n\nOne of those investigations is being conducted by the National Transportation Safety Board, the federal regulator that investigates all manner of accidents, from railroad derailments to some car crashes to virtually all plane crashes.\n\nThe NTSB is scheduled to hold 20 hours of public hearings about the Alaska Airlines incident spread over two days, starting Tuesday morning. It will begin by making public a docket of more than 60 documents running more than 3,800 pages that have been collected in the seven months since the accident.\n\nBoeing executives in charge of quality control will then face the safety board for questions, including Boeing Commercial Airplanes' senior vice president of quality Elizabeth Lund, according to a new agenda posted by the NTSB. Alongside Lund for half of Tuesday's hearing will be Doug Ackerman, vice president of supplier quality for Boeing Commercial Airplanes.\n\nThe NTSB will ask how the Boeing 737 MAX 9 door plug was removed and reinstalled without critical bolts before the plane was delivered to Alaska Airlines. The NTSB will also ask about the \"lack of documentation\" on the factory floor, according to the agenda, as well as changes the manufacturing Goliath implemented after the incident.\n\nThe rare, two-day-long investigative hearing is key to closing the case on the January 5 incident, which led to a 19-day-long grounding of 737 MAX 9s in the United States. The NTSB says it will \"use the information gathered to complete the investigation, determine probable cause, and make recommendations to improve transportation safety.\"\n\nThe NTSB has already released preliminary findings from the incident, disclosing that the plane used on the flight left the Boeing factory in Renton, Washington, 10 weeks earlier and without the four bolts needed to hold the door plug in place.\n\nSince that report, Boeing has said the reasons for that oversight came down to something as simple as a lack of paperwork.\n\nWhen the fuselage of the plane arrived at the Boeing factory from supplier Spirit AeroSystems, the door plug was in place, as were the four bolts meant to hold it securely attached to the side of the jet. But there were problems with five rivets near where the door plug was installed, and Boeing workers removed the door plug in order to fix those rivets.\n\nAccording to Boeing, the workers who fixed the rivets didn't generate the paperwork indicating they had removed the door plug and the four bolts in order to do that work.\n\nWhen a different group of employees put the plug back in place, Boeing says the employees didn't think the plane would actually fly in that condition. Instead, they were just blocking the hole with the plug to protect the inside of the fuselage from weather as the plane moved outside to a different area of the factory compound. That group of employees often makes those kind of temporary fixes.\n\nThose employees likely assumed paperwork existed showing that the plug and bolts had been removed, and that paperwork would prompt someone else along the line to install the bolts. But without the paperwork, no one on the assembly line knew that the door plug had ever been removed, or that its bolts were missing and needed to be replaced.\n\nThe fact that the door plug didn't come out when the plane was at 35,000 feet rather than at a lower altitude with passengers still buckled into their seats is the first part of the good luck.\n\nThe plane made 153 flights with passengers on it from the time it was delivered to Alaska Airlines in late October and the January 5 flight, including 22 flights that took it over the Pacific Ocean for hours flying to and from Hawaii. It would have had much more difficulty making it safely to the ground if the door plug had failed hours, rather than minutes, from the nearest runway.\n\nAnd the fact that the two seats immediately adjacent to the door plug were two of the only seven empty seats on the plane carrying 177 people was very important in preventing fatalities. The force of the air inside the cabin rushing through the hole was enough to twist and bend the metal seats themselves towards the opening. Would-be passengers sitting in those unoccupied seats might not have been able to stay in the the plane, especially if they were not buckled in.\n\nBut perhaps most fortunate of all, when the door plug came out, it fell away from the plane without hitting the tail section, perhaps damaging the the rudder or the vertical stabilizers on the tail, which are crucial to the plane flying straight, level and under control. If that had happened, it would have been very difficult for the plane to land safely, if at all.\n\nBut the probe is only one of the problems Boeing faces because of the incident.\n\nThere could be criminal charges related to the failures that led to the incident, as the FBI has notified passengers and crew members that they might be considered crime victims.\n\nEven before the flight, Boeing faced the possibility of criminal charges because of problems with the 737 Max that were kept hidden from the Federal Aviation Administration during the original certification process. Those problems led to a design flaw on the plane that is blamed for two fatal crashes in 2018 and 2019 that killed 346 people.\n\nIn January 2021, Boeing and the Justice Department agreed to a settlement that deferred criminal prosecution of Boeing for three years for its employees defrauding the FAA during the certification process. But that three-year probationary period had been due to end just days after the January 5 flight. Instead, the DOJ reopened the investigation following the Alaska Airlines incident, and last month Boeing agreed to plead guilty to criminal charges and be put under the supervision of a court-appointed monitor.\n\nThe FAA has also increased scrutiny of Boeing's manufacturing process and is limiting how many planes it can build, which has added to financial losses at the company that have now reached $33 billion since the second fatal crash in 2019.\n\nBoeing's sales have plunged 70% in the first six months of the this year. In June it sold just three passenger jets, and one of those was to Alaska Airlines to replace the plane used in the January 5 flight, which Boeing has repurchased from the airline.\n\nBoeing will get a new boss the day after the hearing ends on Wednesday, as Dave Calhoun, who has served as CEO since January 2020, steps down and Kelly Ortberg, the former CEO of aerospace supplier Rockwell Collins, assumes the top job.\n\nCalhoun's departure is being termed a retirement, and he is 67. But when Boeing's board waived the retirement age for top executives for Calhoun in 2021 so he didn't have to retire after two years on the job, he said he intended to stay \"as long as they want me.\" He could have stayed in the job through 2027 under the waiver granted in 2021.\n\nHe has faced harsh criticism for many of Boeing's problems, with more than a dozen whistleblowers at the company complaining to congressional investigators that they faced pressure and retaliation for flagging safety problems in the company's assembly process.\n\nCalhoun has only testified on Capitol Hill once despite all the attention Boeing has received. In a stunning understatement he conceded the company's safety culture was \"far from perfect,\" but vowed that safety is a priority and that the company is making progress. But that didn't stop a bipartisan grilling at a Senate hearing in June.\n\n\"Why haven't you resigned?,\" he was asked by Senator Josh Hawley during that hearing.\n\n\"Senator, I'm sticking this through,\" he replied. But his plans to leave the company by the end of the year had already been announced by the time of the hearing.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. {"uri": "8262633943", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-07", "time": "00:28:14", "dateTime": "2024-08-07T00:28:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-07T00:27:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.businesstimes.com.sg/companies-markets/transport-logistics/boeing-make-design-changes-prevent-future-737-max-9-door-panel-blowout", "title": "Boeing to make design changes to prevent future 737 MAX 9 door panel blowout", "body": "BOEING said on Tuesday it plans to make design changes to prevent a future mid-air cabin panel blowout like the one in an Alaska Airlines 737 MAX 9 flight in January that spun the planemaker into its second major crisis in recent years.\n\nThe National Transportation Safety Board and Boeing said officials still have not determined who removed and reinstalled that plane's door plug during production.\n\nNTSB completed the first of two days of hearings on Tuesday that lasted nearly 10 hours into the mid-air emergency that badly damaged Boeing's reputation, led to the MAX 9 grounding for two weeks, a ban by the Federal Aviation Administration on expanding production, a criminal investigation and the departure of several key executives.\n\nInvestigators have said the door plug in the new Alaska MAX 9 was missing four key bolts.\n\nBoeing, which has vowed to make key quality improvement, faced extensive questions about the production of the accident MAX 9 and lack of paperwork documenting the removal of the door plug.\n\nNTSB Chair Jennifer Homendy on Tuesday criticised the planemaker's safety culture, asking why it had not made improvements earlier and said it must takes steps to improve. \"The safety culture needs a lot of work,\" Homendy said.\n\nBoeing's senior vice-president for quality Elizabeth Lund said the planemaker is working on design changes that it hopes to implement within the year and then to retrofit across the fleet.\n\n\"They are working on some design changes that will allow the door plug to not be closed if there's any issue until it's firmly secured,\" Lund said.\n\nLund said two Boeing employees who were likely involved in the opening of the door plug have been placed on paid administrative leave.\n\nThe board also released 3,800 pages of factual reports and interviews from the ongoing investigation.\n\nBoeing has said no paperwork exists to document the removal of four key missing bolts. Lund said Boeing has now put a bright blue and yellow sign on the door plug when it arrives at the factory that says in big letters: \"Do not open\" and adds a redundancy \"to ensure that the plug is not inadvertently opened.\"\n\nA flight attendant described a moment of terror when the door plug blew out. \"And then, just all of a sudden, there was just a really loud bang and lots of whooshing air, like the door burst open,\" the flight attendant said. \"Masks came down, I saw the galley curtain get sucked towards the cabin.\"\n\nDoug Ackerman, vice-president of supplier quality for Boeing said Boeing has 1,200 active suppliers for its commercial airplanes and 200 supplier quality auditors.\n\nLund said on Tuesday Boeing is still building \"in the 20s\" for monthly MAX production - far fewer MAXs than the 38 per month it is allowed to produce. \"We are working our way back up. But at one point I think we were as low as eight,\" Lund told the NTSB.\n\nLast month, Boeing agreed to buy back Spirit AeroSystems, whose core plants it spun off in 2005, for US$4.7 billion in stock.\n\nThe hearings are reviewing key issues, including 737 manufacturing and inspections, safety management and quality management systems, FAA oversight, and issues surrounding the opening and closing of the door plug.\n\nFuselage defects\n\nJonathan Arnold, Aviation Safety Inspector at the FAA, said a systemic issue he witnessed at Boeing's factory was employees not following the instructions.\n\n\"That seems to be systemic where they deviate from their instructions. And typically, tool control is what I see most,\" Arnold said.\n\nLund said before the Jan 5 accident, every 737 fuselage delivered to Boeing by Spirit AeroSystems had defects.\n\n\"What we don't want is the really big defects that are impactful to the production system,\" Lund said. \"We were starting to see more and more of those kinds of issues, I will tell you, right around the time of the accident.\"\n\nHomendy at one point expressed frustration with Boeing. \"The safety culture needs a lot of work (at Boeing),\" she said. \"There's not a lot of trust, there's a lot of distrust within the workforce.\"\n\nBoeing executive Carole Murray described various problems with fuselages coming from Spirit AeroSystems in the run-up to the accident. \"We had defects. Sealant was one of our biggest defects that we had write-ups on,\" she said. \"We had multiple escapements around the window frame, skin defects.\"\n\nMichelle Delgado, a structures mechanic who worked as a contractor at Boeing and did the rework on the Alaska MAX 9 aircraft, told NTSB the workload is heavy and requires working long hours.\n\n\"In order for me to not have to deal with a worse situation tomorrow, I'd rather work a 12 to 13-hour shift to get it all done, for my sake, so I don't have to deal with people the next day,\" he told NTSB.\n\nAlso in June, the NTSB said Boeing violated investigation rules when Lund provided non-public information to media and speculated about possible causes.\n\nLast month, Boeing agreed to plead guilty to a criminal fraud conspiracy charge and pay a fine of at least US$243.6 million to resolve a Justice Department investigation into two 737 MAX fatal crashes. {"uri": "8261174754", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "05:36:10", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T05:36:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T05:35:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://vir.com.vn/hearing-to-probe-alaska-airlines-emergency-on-boeing-jet-113343.html", "title": "Hearing to probe Alaska Airlines emergency on Boeing jet", "body": "Video of the episode showed oxygen masks hanging in front of a gaping airplane space from a panel that blew out shortly after takeoff, leaving passengers exposed to open air at an altitude of about 16,000 feet.\n\nThe hearing in Washington aims \"to determine the facts, circumstances, and probable cause of the transportation accident... and to make recommendations to improve transportation safety,\" said the National Transportation Safety Board, which is overseeing the probe.\n\nThe plane soon went back to Portland where it safely landed, although there were eight minor injuries.\n\nThe NTSB immediately launched a probe and after a month said four bolts securing the panel were missing, according to preliminary findings released February 6.\n\nThe agency has collected written documents and photos showing that Boeing employees removed four bolts from these locations during an inspection at the Renton plant in Washington state prior to delivery of the aircraft last October.\n\nOver the course of two day-long sessions on Tuesday and Wednesday in Washington, the NTSB will hear from about 15 witnesses.\n\nSpeakers include Elizabeth Lund, senior vice president for quality at Boeing, among other officials at the company, as well as officials from key supplier Spirit AeroSystems, regulator Federal Aviation Administration and the machinists union.\n\nThe witness list does not include Alaska Airlines.\n\nLund came under fire from the NTSB after providing a detailed summary of the incident in June to journalists touring the company's Renton plant.\n\nBoeing staff identified five \"non-conforming\" rivets in the fuselage after the arrived in Renton, but the issue \"did not create a safety hazard,\" Lund told reporters.\n\nBut when the fuselage panel, known as the door plug, was removed to replace the rivets, Boeing staff failed to file the documentation to make the change on the door plug, Lund said.\n\n\"We believe that plug was opened without the correct paperwork,\" Lund told reporters. \"There was a non-compliance to our processes at that point.\"\n\nShe also said Boeing was focused on closing a \"gap\" over the lack of documentation and that determining who did the work \"is the responsibility of the NTSB and that investigation is still going on.\"\n\n- Boeing sanctioned -\n\nAfter Lund's comments were published in June, the NTSB announced it was sanctioning the company for sharing details about an ongoing probe that were not supposed to be discussed publicly.\n\nLund \"released non-public investigative information and made unsubstantiated speculations about possible causes of the Jan. 5 door-plug blowout, which is directly at issue in the ongoing investigation,\" the NTSB said in a June 27 letter to Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun.\n\nSome of the information \"was either inaccurate or unknown to the NTSB,\" the letter added. \"This disregard of the federal regulations and rules governing NTSB investigations cannot be tolerated.\"\n\nAs a result, the NTSB said it is blocking Boeing from reviewing information gathered in its investigation and will not permit the company to ask questions of other witnesses at the hearing.\n\nNTSB Chair Jennifer Homendy in March had also sharply criticized Boeing's handling of the probe, telling a congressional hearing the company was dragging its feet in providing key documentation and witnesses involved in working on the plane.\n\nTuesday's hearing comes as Boeing faces heavy scrutiny from regulators following the January incident and in the wake of congressional testimony from whistleblowers who say the company punishes workers who raise safety issues while moving to cover up problems.", "source": {"uri": "vir.com.vn", "dataType": "news", "title": "Vietnam {"uri": "8262549572", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "22:42:35", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T22:42:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T22:41:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.unionleader.com/news/business/transportation/boeing-to-make-design-changes-to-prevent-future-737-max-9-door-panel-blowout/article_31bcd30e-3d52-5c62-8be4-b4cbdb71a47f.html", "title": "Boeing to make design changes to prevent future 737 MAX 9 door panel blowout", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Boeing said on Tuesday it plans to make design changes to prevent a future mid-air cabin panel blowout like the one in an Alaska Airlines 737 MAX 9 flight in January that spun the planemaker into its second major crisis in recent years.\n\nBoeing's senior vice president for quality, Elizabeth Lund said the planemaker is working on design changes that it hopes to implement within the year and then to retrofit across the fleet.\n\nInvestigators have said the plug in the new Alaska MAX 9 was missing four key bolts.\n\n\"They are working on some design changes that will allow the door plug to not be closed if there's any issue until it's firmly secured,\" Lund said during the first of a two-day National Transportation Safety Board investigative hearing in Washington.\n\nLund's comments followed questioning on why Boeing did not use a type of warning system for door plugs that the planemaker includes on regular doors that sends an alert if it is not fully secure.\n\nThe incident badly damaged Boeing's reputation and led to the MAX 9 being grounded for two weeks, a ban by the FAA on expanding production, a criminal investigation and the departure of several key executives. Boeing has vowed to make key quality improvements.\n\nThe board also released 3,800 pages of factual reports and interviews from the ongoing investigation.\n\nBoeing has said no paperwork exists to document the removal of four key missing bolts. Lund said Boeing has now put a bright blue and yellow sign on the door plug when it arrives at the factory that says in big letters: \"Do not open\" and adds a redundancy \"to ensure that the plug is not inadvertently opened.\" It also has new required procedures if the door plug needs to be opened during production.\n\nA flight attendant described a moment of terror when the door plug blew out. \"And then, just all of a sudden, there was just a really loud bang and lots of whooshing air, like the door burst open,\" the flight attendant said. \"Masks came down, I saw the galley curtain get sucked towards the cabin.\"\n\nLund and Doug Ackerman, vice president of supplier quality for Boeing, are testifying Tuesday during the hearings scheduled to last 20 hours over two days. Ackerman said Boeing has 1,200 active suppliers for its commercial airplanes and 200 supplier quality auditors.\n\nLund said Tuesday Boeing is still building \"in the 20s\" for monthly MAX production -- far fewer MAXs than the 38 per month it is allowed to produce. \"We are working our way back up. But at one point I think we were as low as eight,\" Lund told the NTSB.\n\nTerry George, senior vice president and general manager for Boeing Program at Spirit AeroSystems, and Scott Grabon, a senior director for 737 quality at Spirit, which makes the fuselage for the MAX, also testified Tuesday.\n\nLast month Boeing agreed to buy back Spirit AeroSystems, whose core plants it spun off in 2005, for $4.7 billion in stock.\n\nThe hearing is reviewing issues including 737 manufacturing and inspections, safety management and quality management systems, FAA oversight, and issues surrounding the opening and closing of the door plug.\n\nFuselage defects\n\nIn June, FAA Administrator Mike Whitaker said the agency was \"too hands off\" in its oversight of Boeing before January. FAA employees told the NTSB that Boeing employees did not always followed required processes.\n\nJonathan Arnold, Aviation Safety Inspector at the FAA, said a systemic issue he witnessed at Boeing's factory was employees not following the instructions.\n\n\"That seems to be systemic where they deviate from their instructions. And typically, tool control is what I see most,\" Arnold said.\n\nLund said before the Jan. 5 accident, every 737 fuselage delivered to Boeing had defects - but the key is making sure they are manageable. \"What we don't want is the really big defects that are impactful to the production system,\" Lund said. \"We were starting to see more and more of those kinds of issues, I will tell you, right around the time of the accident.\"\n\nNational Transportation Safety Board chair Jennifer Homendy at one point expressed frustration with Boeing. \"This isn't a PR campaign for Boeing,\" she said, urging the company to make clear what its policies were before the incident.\n\nThe interviews also addressed questions of factory culture, which has been under fire in congressional hearings. Whistleblowers have alleged that Boeing retaliated against people coming forward with safety concerns on the factory floor.\n\nBoeing executive Carole Murray described various problems with fuselages coming from Spirit AeroSystems in the run-up to the accident. \"We had defects. Sealant was one of our biggest defects that we had write-ups on,\" she said. \"We had multiple escapements around the window frame, skin defects.\"\n\nMichelle Delgado, a structures mechanic who worked as a contractor at Boeing and did the rework on the Alaska MAX 9 aircraft, told NTSB the workload is heavy and requires working long hours.\n\n\"When we're very overwhelmed with work, it is pressing because with everything we've cut down on some personnel, so now it's like in order for me to not have to deal with a worse situation tomorrow, I'd rather work a 12 to 13-hour shift to get it all done, for my sake, so I don't have to deal with people the next day.\"\n\nAlso in June, the NTSB said Boeing violated investigation rules when Lund provided non-public information to media and speculated about possible causes.\n\nLast month, Boeing agreed to plead guilty to a criminal fraud conspiracy charge and pay a fine of at least $243.6 million to resolve a Justice Department investigation into two 737 MAX fatal crashes.", "source": {"uri": "unionleader.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "UnionLeader.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "reuters@unionleader.com", "name": "Reuters", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MAX_Light_Rail", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "MAX Light Rail"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_United_States", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Vice President of the United States"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Boeing"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Aviation_Administration", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Federal Aviation "Washington (state)"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lund", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Lund"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Lund"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Sweden"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Screw", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"uri": "2024-08-445881767", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "15:15:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T15:15:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T15:15:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.gulf-times.com/article/688100/international/uslatin-america/us-ntsb-opens-hearing-on-alaska-airlines-boeing-737-max-cabin-panel-blowout", "title": "US NTSB opens hearing on Alaska Airlines' Boeing 737 MAX cabin panel blowout", "body": "The US National Transportation Safety Board on Tuesday is questioning key witnesses from Boeing, Spirit AeroSystems and the Federal Aviation Administration on the mid-air cabin panel blowout of an Alaska Airlines 737 MAX 9 door plug in January.\n\nDuring the start of its two-day investigative hearing, the board released 3,800 pages of factual reports and interviews from the ongoing investigation.\n\nThe incident badly damaged Boeing's reputation and led to the MAX 9 being grounded for two weeks, a ban by the FAA on expanding production, a criminal investigation and the departure of several key executives. Boeing has vowed to make key quality improvements.\n\nBoeing's senior vice president for quality, Elizabeth Lund, and Doug Ackerman, vice president of supplier quality for Boeing, are testifying Tuesday during the hearings scheduled to last 20 hours over two days.\n\nLund said Tuesday Boeing is still building \"in the 20s\" for monthly MAX production - far fewer MAXs than the 38 per month it is allowed to produce. \"We are working our way back up. But at one point I think we were as low as eight,\" Lund told the NTSB.\n\nA flight attendant described a moment of terror when the door plug blew out. \"And then, just all of a sudden, there was just a really loud bang and lots of whooshing air, like the door burst open,\" the flight attendant said. \"Masks came down, I saw the galley curtain get sucked towards the cabin.\"\n\nTerry George, senior vice president and general manager for Boeing Program at Spirit AeroSystems, and Scott Grabon, a senior director for 737 quality at Spirit, which makes the fuselage for the MAX, also testified Tuesday.\n\nLast month Boeing agreed to buy back Spirit AeroSystems, whose core plants it spun off in 2005, for $4.7 billion in stock.\n\nThe hearing will review issues including 737 manufacturing and inspections, safety management and quality management systems, FAA oversight, and issues surrounding the opening and closing of the door plug.\n\nBoeing has said no paperwork exists to document the removal of four key missing bolts. Lund said Boeing has now put a bright blue and yellow sign on the door plug when it arrives at the factory that says in big letters: \"Do not open\" and adds a redundancy \"to ensure that the plug is not inadvertently opened.\"\n\nIn June, FAA Administrator Mike Whitaker said the agency was \"too hands off\" in its oversight of Boeing before January. FAA employees told the NTSB that Boeing employees did not always followed required processes.\n\nJonathan Arnold, Aviation Safety Inspector at the FAA, said a systemic issue he witnessed at Boeing's factory was employees not following the instructions.\n\n\"That seems to be systemic where they deviate from their instructions. And typically, tool control is what I see most,\" Arnold said.\n\nThe interviews also addressed questions of factory culture, which has been under fire in Congressional hearings. Whistleblowers have alleged that Boeing retaliated against people coming forward with safety concerns on the factory floor.\n\nBoeing's former overall head of quality Carole Murray disclosed Boeing was under pressure from regulators to simplify its processes, whose complexity she likened to a \"fireworks show\".\n\n\"If you map out our documentation right now, it kind of looks like a fireworks show, and we've been told by our regulators and our teams that our processes are complicated. And it's going to take significant effort to go change that because they're so intertwined,\" she told the NTSB.\n\nAlso in June, the NTSB said Boeing violated investigation rules when Lund provided non-public information to media and speculated about possible causes.\n\nLast month, Boeing agreed to plead guilty to a criminal fraud conspiracy charge and pay a fine of at least $243.6 million to resolve a Justice Department investigation into two 737 MAX fatal crashes.", "source": {"uri": "gulf-times.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Gulf-Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-446222030", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "22:25:09", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T22:25:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T22:21:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.ibtimes.com.au/us-officials-press-answers-boeing-emergency-alaska-airlines-1850336", "title": "US Officials Press For Answers On Boeing Emergency On Alaska Airlines", "body": "US transportation investigators pressed officials from Boeing and a top supplier on Tuesday over manufacturing lapses that led to a near-catastrophic January incident on a 737 MAX that necessitated an emergency landing.\n\nIn the two-day hearing, which concludes Wednesday, the National Transportation Safety Board aims to pinpoint what went wrong and craft recommendations after a fuselage panel known as a door-plug suddenly came off mid-flight on an Alaska Airlines plane.\n\nVideo of the episode showed oxygen masks hanging in front of a gaping hole in the plane after the panel blew out shortly after takeoff, leaving passengers exposed to open air at an altitude of about 16,000 feet.\n\nThe NTSB has previously said that four bolts securing the panel were missing, according to preliminary findings.\n\nAfter morning questions that touched on employee training and policies around change orders, an afternoon session dug into the details on repair work performed on the door-plug that was not properly documented.\n\nWhen the fuselage was shipped by train to Boeing's Renton, Washington, facility on August 31, 2023, from supplier Spirit AeroSystems, evidence showed that the bolts were in place, NTSB investigator in charge John Lovell said at the outset of Tuesday's session.\n\nBoeing staff performed work on the part beginning early in the morning of September 18 until late in the evening of September 19 before the jet was delivered to Alaska Airlines, Lovell said.\n\nThe work was needed after Boeing staff determined rivets were not in conformance with standards.\n\nLovell said that the rivets were replaced under a non-conformance order, with the work conducted by Spirit personnel at Boeing's Renton factory.\n\nBut while Spirit personnel performed the work on the rivets, Spirit was not authorized to remove or reinstall the door plug and would not have done so, Spirit's Michael Riney testified.\n\nWhen the door plug was removed to replace the rivets, workers failed to file the documentation to make the change on the door plug, according to Elizabeth Lund, senior vice president for quality at Boeing.\n\nAs a result, there was also no documentation for when the door plug was reinstalled. Lund told the panel that Boeing door staff would have been authorized to open or close the door plug.\n\nLund told the panel that the \"primary\" place to identify the lapse would have been through such documentation, \"open paperwork, which we don't believe existed.\"\n\nSumming up this issue later, NTSB Chair Jennifer Homendy asked Lund late Tuesday afternoon, \"We do not know specifically when this door plug ... We do not know by whom.\"\n\n\"Correct,\" Lund responded.\n\nThe two-day hearing continues Wednesday, with sessions involving Boeing's quality management and oversight by the Federal Aviation Administration.\n\nHomendy said the hearing should focus on unanswered questions and Boeing's operations before the Alaska Airlines incident rather than steps Boeing has taken in the aftermath.\n\n\"This is not a PR campaign for Boeing,\" said NTSB Chair Jennifer Homendy. \"What I want to know, what we want to know, is what happened\" in the period before January 5.\n\nLund came under fire from the NTSB after discussing the probe in a Boeing-hosted tour of Renton, with the agency sanctioning Boeing for sharing details about an ongoing probe that were not supposed to be discussed publicly.\n\nAs a result, the NTSB said it is blocking Boeing from reviewing information gathered in its investigation and will not permit the company to ask questions of other witnesses at the hearing.\n\nHomendy in March had also sharply criticized Boeing's handling of the probe, telling a congressional hearing the company was dragging its feet in providing key documentation and witnesses involved in working on the plane.\n\nTuesday's hearing comes as Boeing faces heavy scrutiny from regulators following the January incident and in the wake of congressional testimony from whistleblowers who say the company punishes workers who raise safety issues while moving to cover up problems.\n\nLund acknowledged the need for better communications and the simplification of some procedures at Boeing, but stressed that the company was committed to improving.\n\nLund recounted a quality \"stand down\" in which some 70,000 workers took an eight-hour work day to review safety policies. The company took 30,000 recommendations of employee feedback on \"how we can improve quality or product safety.\"\n\nBut prior to the January 5 incident Boeing's \"training was in really bad shape,\" said Lloyd Catlin, of the International Association of Machinists. \"There has been changes, but I don't know that it is enough.\"", "source": {"uri": "ibtimes.com.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "dmoz/Health/Senses/Hearing", "label": "dmoz/Health/Senses/Hearing", "wgt": 11}, {"uri": "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 79}], "image": "https://d.ibtimes.com.au/en/full/1856057/two-day-hearing-set-investigate-what-happened-january-5-alaska-airlines-flight-which-panel.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9793139", "eventUri": "eng-9793139", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-09-18", "textStart": 1350, "textEnd": 1362}, {"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-09-19", "textStart": 1392, "textEnd": 1404}, {"amb": false, "date": "-01-05", "textStart": 3136, "textEnd": 3145, "freq": 2}], "sentiment": -0.1215686274509804, "wgt": 195, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-08-445539330", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "10:14:20", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T10:14:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T10:00:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.wsiltv.com/news/consumer/we-re-about-to-get-the-most-detailed-explanation-yet-for-boeing-s-terrifying-mid/article_40542958-8a3f-5fd9-a67f-eee37ae6c34c.html", "title": "We're about to get the most detailed explanation yet for Boeing's terrifying mid-air blowout", "body": "(CNN) -- The public already knows a lot about the January 5 Alaska Airlines flight that had a door plug blow out of the side of a Boeing 737 Max as it approached 16,000 feet. On Tuesday, we could find out a lot more.\n\nThe incident left a gaping hole in the side of the plane, sending oxygen masks falling from the ceiling, tearing off clothing and ripping phones out of passengers' hands and hurling them into the darkness.\n\nFortunately, the crew was able to land the crippled jet without any serious injuries. It was a combination of the skill of the flight crew and good luck that no one was killed. The accident did do serious damage to the public's confidence in plane manufacturer Boeing, prompting a series of federal investigations into its practices and the safety and quality of its aircraft.\n\nOne of those investigations is being conducted by the National Transportation Safety Board, the federal regulator that investigates all manner of accidents, from railroad derailments to some car crashes to virtually all plane crashes.\n\nThe NTSB is scheduled to hold 20 hours of public hearings about the Alaska Airlines incident spread over two days, starting Tuesday morning. It will begin by making public a docket of more than 60 documents running more than 3,800 pages that have been collected in the seven months since the accident.\n\nBoeing executives in charge of quality control will then face the safety board for questions, including Boeing Commercial Airplanes' senior vice president of quality Elizabeth Lund, according to a new agenda posted by the NTSB. Alongside Lund for half of Tuesday's hearing will be Doug Ackerman, vice president of supplier quality for Boeing Commercial Airplanes.\n\nThe NTSB will ask how the Boeing 737 MAX 9 door plug was removed and reinstalled without critical bolts before the plane was delivered to Alaska Airlines. The NTSB will also ask about the \"lack of documentation\" on the factory floor, according to the agenda, as well as changes the manufacturing Goliath implemented after the incident.\n\nThe rare, two-day-long investigative hearing is key to closing the case on the January 5 incident, which led to a 19-day-long grounding of 737 MAX 9s in the United States. The NTSB says it will \"use the information gathered to complete the investigation, determine probable cause, and make recommendations to improve transportation safety.\"\n\nA final report is still months away.\n\nMissing bolts -- and missing paperwork\n\nThe NTSB has already released preliminary findings from the incident, disclosing that the plane used on the flight left the Boeing factory in Renton, Washington, 10 weeks earlier and without the four bolts needed to hold the door plug in place.\n\nSince that report, Boeing has said the reasons for that oversight came down to something as simple as a lack of paperwork.\n\nWhen the fuselage of the plane arrived at the Boeing factory from supplier Spirit AeroSystems, the door plug was in place, as were the four bolts meant to hold it securely attached to the side of the jet. But there were problems with five rivets near where the door plug was installed, and Boeing workers removed the door plug in order to fix those rivets.\n\nAccording to Boeing, the workers who fixed the rivets didn't generate the paperwork indicating they had removed the door plug and the four bolts in order to do that work.\n\nWhen a different group of employees put the plug back in place, Boeing says the employees didn't think the plane would actually fly in that condition. Instead, they were just blocking the hole with the plug to protect the inside of the fuselage from weather as the plane moved outside to a different area of the factory compound. That group of employees often makes those kind of temporary fixes.\n\nThose employees likely assumed paperwork existed showing that the plug and bolts had been removed, and that paperwork would prompt someone else along the line to install the bolts. But without the paperwork, no one on the assembly line knew that the door plug had ever been removed, or that its bolts were missing and needed to be replaced.\n\nTragedy narrowly averted\n\nThe fact that the door plug didn't come out when the plane was at 35,000 feet rather than at a lower altitude with passengers still buckled into their seats is the first part of the good luck.\n\nThe plane made 153 flights with passengers on it from the time it was delivered to Alaska Airlines in late October and the January 5 flight, including 22 flights that took it over the Pacific Ocean for hours flying to and from Hawaii. It would have had much more difficulty making it safely to the ground if the door plug had failed hours, rather than minutes, from the nearest runway.\n\nAnd the fact that the two seats immediately adjacent to the door plug were two of the only seven empty seats on the plane carrying 177 people was very important in preventing fatalities. The force of the air inside the cabin rushing through the hole was enough to twist and bend the metal seats themselves towards the opening. Would-be passengers sitting in those unoccupied seats might not have been able to stay in the the plane, especially if they were not buckled in.\n\nBut perhaps most fortunate of all, when the door plug came out, it fell away from the plane without hitting the tail section, perhaps damaging the the rudder or the vertical stabilizers on the tail, which are crucial to the plane flying straight, level and under control. If that had happened, it would have been very difficult for the plane to land safely, if at all.\n\nBoeing's mounting problems\n\nBut the probe is only one of the problems Boeing faces because of the incident.\n\nThere could be criminal charges related to the failures that led to the incident, as the FBI has notified passengers and crew members that they might be considered crime victims.\n\nEven before the flight, Boeing faced the possibility of criminal charges because of problems with the 737 Max that were kept hidden from the Federal Aviation Administration during the original certification process. Those problems led to a design flaw on the plane that is blamed for two fatal crashes in 2018 and 2019 that killed 346 people.\n\nIn January 2021, Boeing and the Justice Department agreed to a settlement that deferred criminal prosecution of Boeing for three years for its employees defrauding the FAA during the certification process. But that three-year probationary period had been due to end just days after the January 5 flight. Instead, the DOJ reopened the investigation following the Alaska Airlines incident, and last month Boeing agreed to plead guilty to criminal charges and be put under the supervision of a court-appointed monitor.\n\nThe FAA has also increased scrutiny of Boeing's manufacturing process and is limiting how many planes it can build, which has added to financial losses at the company that have now reached $33 billion since the second fatal crash in 2019.\n\nBoeing's sales have plunged 70% in the first six months of the this year. In June it sold just three passenger jets, and one of those was to Alaska Airlines to replace the plane used in the January 5 flight, which Boeing has repurchased from the airline.\n\nLast days of current leadership\n\nBoeing will get a new boss the day after the hearing ends on Wednesday, as Dave Calhoun, who has served as CEO since January 2020, steps down and Kelly Ortberg, the former CEO of aerospace supplier Rockwell Collins, assumes the top job.\n\nCalhoun's departure is being termed a retirement, and he is 67. But when Boeing's board waived the retirement age for top executives for Calhoun in 2021 so he didn't have to retire after two years on the job, he said he intended to stay \"as long as they want me.\" He could have stayed in the job through 2027 under the waiver granted in 2021.\n\nHe has faced harsh criticism for many of Boeing's problems, with more than a dozen whistleblowers at the company complaining to congressional investigators that they faced pressure and retaliation for flagging safety problems in the company's assembly process.\n\nCalhoun has only testified on Capitol Hill once despite all the attention Boeing has received. In a stunning understatement he conceded the company's safety culture was \"far from perfect,\" but vowed that safety is a priority and that the company is making progress. But that didn't stop a bipartisan grilling at a Senate hearing in June.\n\n\"Why haven't you resigned?,\" he was asked by Senator Josh Hawley during that hearing.\n\n\"Senator, I'm sticking this through,\" he replied. But his plans to leave the company by the end of the year had already been announced by the time of the hearing.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. {"uri": "2024-08-445956864", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "16:30:43", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T16:30:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T16:15:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.businesstimes.com.sg/companies-markets/transport-logistics/boeing-details-production-issues-737-max-9-mid-air-emergency-hearing", "title": "Boeing details production issues at 737 MAX 9 mid-air emergency hearing", "body": "THE US National Transportation Safety Board on Tuesday (Aug 6) is questioning key witnesses from Boeing, Spirit AeroSystems and the Federal Aviation Administration on the mid-air cabin panel blowout of an Alaska Airlines 737 MAX 9 door plug in January.\n\nDuring the start of its two-day investigative hearing, the board released 3,800 pages of factual reports and interviews from the ongoing investigation.\n\nThe incident badly damaged Boeing's reputation and led to the MAX 9 being grounded for two weeks, a ban by the FAA on expanding production, a criminal investigation and the departure of several key executives. Boeing has vowed to make key quality improvements.\n\nBoeing's senior vice-president for quality, Elizabeth Lund, and Doug Ackerman, vice-president of supplier quality for Boeing, are testifying on Tuesday during the hearings scheduled to last 20 hours over two days. Ackerman said Boeing has 1,200 active suppliers for its commercial airplanes and 200 supplier quality auditors.\n\nLund said on Tuesday Boeing is still building \"in the 20s\" for monthly MAX production - far fewer MAXs than the 38 per month it is allowed to produce. \"We are working our way back up. But at one point I think we were as low as eight,\" Lund told the NTSB.\n\nA flight attendant described a moment of terror when the door plug blew out. \"And then, just all of a sudden, there was just a really loud bang and lots of whooshing air, like the door burst open,\" the flight attendant said. \"Masks came down, I saw the galley curtain get sucked towards the cabin.\"\n\nTerry George, senior vice-president and general manager for Boeing Program at Spirit AeroSystems, and Scott Grabon, a senior director for 737 quality at Spirit, which makes the fuselage for the MAX, also testified on Tuesday.\n\nLast month Boeing agreed to buy back Spirit AeroSystems, whose core plants it spun off in 2005, for US$4.7 billion in stock.\n\nThe hearing is reviewing issues including 737 manufacturing and inspections, safety management and quality management systems, FAA oversight, and issues surrounding the opening and closing of the door plug.\n\n'Too hands off'\n\nBoeing has said no paperwork exists to document the removal of four key missing bolts. Lund said Boeing has now put a bright blue and yellow sign on the door plug when it arrives at the factory that says in big letters: \"Do not open\" and adds a redundancy \"to ensure that the plug is not inadvertently opened.\"\n\nIn June, FAA Administrator Mike Whitaker said the agency was \"too hands off\" in its oversight of Boeing before January. FAA employees told the NTSB that Boeing employees did not always followed required processes.\n\nJonathan Arnold, Aviation Safety Inspector at the FAA, said a systemic issue he witnessed at Boeing's factory was employees not following the instructions.\n\n\"That seems to be systemic where they deviate from their instructions. And typically, tool control is what I see most,\" Arnold said.\n\nLund said before the Jan five accident, every 737 fuselage delivered to Boeing had defects - but the key is making sure they are manageable. \"What we don't want is the really big defects that are impactful to the production system,\" Lund said. \"We were starting to see more and more of those kinds of issues. I will tell you right around the time of the accident.\"\n\nThe interviews also addressed questions of factory culture, which has been under fire in congressional hearings. Whistleblowers have alleged that Boeing retaliated against people coming forward with safety concerns on the factory floor.\n\nBoeing executive Carole Murray described various problems with fuselages coming from Spirit AeroSystems in the run-up to the accident. \"We had defects. Sealant was one of our biggest defects that we had write-ups on,\" she said. \"We had multiple escapements around the window frame, skin defects.\"\n\nMichelle Delgado, a structures mechanic who worked as a contractor at Boeing and did the rework on the Alaska MAX 9 aircraft, told NTSB the workload is heavy and requires working long hours.\n\n\"When we're very overwhelmed with work, it is pressing because with everything we've cut down on some personnel, so now it's like in order for me to not have to deal with a worse situation tomorrow, I'd rather work a 12 to 13-hour shift to get it all done, for my sake, so I don't have to deal with people the next day.\"\n\nAlso in June, the NTSB said Boeing violated investigation rules when Lund provided non-public information to media and speculated about possible causes.\n\nLast month, Boeing agreed to plead guilty to a criminal fraud conspiracy charge and pay a fine of at least US$243.6 million to resolve a Justice Department investigation into two 737 MAX fatal crashes. UrduPoint", "body": "New York, (APP - UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News - 6th Aug, 2024) US investigators will on Tuesday open a two-day hearing into a near-catastrophic January incident on a Boeing 737 MAX operated by Alaska Airlines that required an emergency landing.\n\nVideo of the episode showed oxygen masks hanging in front of a gaping airplane space from a panel that blew out shortly after takeoff, leaving passengers exposed to open air at an altitude of about 16,000 feet.\n\nThe hearing in Washington aims \"to determine the facts, circumstances, and probable cause of the transportation accident... and to make recommendations to improve transportation safety,\" said the National Transportation Safety board, which is overseeing the probe.\n\nThe plane soon went back to Portland where it safely landed, although there were eight minor injuries.\n\nThe NTSB immediately launched a probe and after a month said four bolts securing the panel were missing, according to preliminary findings released February 6.\n\nThe agency has collected written documents and photos showing that Boeing employees removed four bolts from these locations during an inspection at the Renton plant in Washington state prior to delivery of the aircraft last October.\n\nThe witness list does not include Alaska Airlines.\n\nLund came under fire from the NTSB after providing a detailed summary of the incident in June to journalists touring the company's Renton plant.\n\nBoeing staff identified five \"non-conforming\" rivets in the fuselage after the arrived in Renton, but the issue \"did not create a safety hazard,\" Lund told reporters.\n\nBut when the fuselage panel, known as the door plug, was removed to replace the rivets, Boeing staff failed to file the documentation to make the change on the door plug, Lund said.\n\n\"We believe that plug was opened without the correct paperwork,\" Lund told reporters. \"There was a non-compliance to our processes at that point.\"\n\nShe also said Boeing was focused on closing a \"gap\" over the lack of documentation and that determining who did the work \"is the responsibility of the NTSB and that investigation is still going on.\"\n\nAfter Lund's comments were published in June, the NTSB announced it was sanctioning the company for sharing details about an ongoing probe that were not supposed to be discussed publicly.\n\nLund \"released non-public investigative information and made unsubstantiated speculations about possible causes of the Jan. 5 door-plug blowout, which is directly at issue in the ongoing investigation,\" the NTSB said in a June 27 letter to Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun.\n\nSome of the information \"was either inaccurate or unknown to the NTSB,\" the letter added. \"This disregard of the federal regulations and rules governing NTSB investigations cannot be tolerated.\"\n\nAs a result, the NTSB said it is blocking Boeing from reviewing information gathered in its investigation and will not permit the company to ask questions of other witnesses at the hearing.\n\nNTSB Chair Jennifer Homendy in March had also sharply criticized Boeing's handling of the probe, telling a congressional {"uri": "8262442197", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "20:48:01", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T20:48:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T20:46:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/business/3044363-ntsb-calls-for-boeing-to-overhaul-safety-culture-after-737-max-incident", "title": "NTSB Calls for Boeing to Overhaul Safety Culture After 737 MAX Incident | Business", "body": "The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) and Boeing are investigating an in-flight emergency involving a new 737 MAX 9 Alaska Airlines aircraft. The incident, caused by a missing door plug, has highlighted significant issues within Boeing's safety culture, leading to calls for improvements from both the NTSB and the Federal Aviation Administration.\n\nThe National Transportation Safety Board and Boeing have been unable to determine who removed a door plug in a new 737 MAX 9 Alaska Airlines aircraft that experienced an in-flight emergency in January, NTSB Chair Jennifer Homendy said on Tuesday. She emphasized Boeing's need for significant improvements in its safety practices.\n\n\"The safety culture needs a lot of work (at Boeing),\" she stated. \"There's not a lot of trust within the workforce,\" she added. The Federal Aviation Administration has also asserted that Boeing must improve its safety culture and address quality issues before ramping up 737 MAX production.\n\nBoeing did not immediately comment. The NTSB reported the 737 MAX 9 was missing four key bolts. Boeing acknowledged that required documents for the door plug removal were never created. Additionally, Boeing has now labeled the door plug with big blue and yellow signs reading \"Do not open.\"\n\nHomendy noted the NTSB has not been able to interview the door plug team manager, who is on medical leave. Earlier this year, the NTSB pressured Boeing for the names of the 25 employees who worked on the door plug. Interviews and written statements have been gathered, though all written statements ended with the suspiciously uniform line: \"I have no knowledge,\" raising further questions.", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Devdiscourse"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_National_(Abu_Dhabi)", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "The National (Abu Dhabi)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_737_MAX", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Boeing 737 MAX"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Boeing"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Transportation_Safety_Board", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "National Transportation Safety Board"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alaska_Airlines", "type": "org", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Alaska Airlines"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Aviation_Administration", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Federal Aviation Administration"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bolt_(fastener)", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Bolt (fastener)"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Transportation", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Transportation", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Travel/Transportation", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Travel/Transportation", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Aviation/Multimedia", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Aviation/Multimedia", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 64}], "image": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/remote.axd?https://devdiscourse.blob.core.windows.net/aiimagegallery/06_08_2024_20_43_40_8398189.png?width=920&format=jpeg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9793139", "eventUri": "eng-9793139", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.1607843137254903, "wgt": 191, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8261944287", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "14:10:47", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T14:10:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T14:05:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13714589/US-NTSB-opens-hearing-Boeing-737-MAX-9-mid-air-emergency.html", "title": "US NTSB opens hearing on Boeing 737 MAX 9 mid-air emergency", "body": "By David Shepardson, Allison Lampert and Abhijith Ganapavaram\n\nWASHINGTON, Aug 6 (Reuters) - The U.S. National Transportation Safety Board on Tuesday is questioning key witnesses from Boeing, Spirit AeroSystems and the Federal Aviation Administration on the mid-air cabin panel blowout of an Alaska Airlines 737 MAX 9 door plug in January.\n\nDuring the start of its two-day investigative hearing, the board released 3,800 pages of factual reports and interviews from the ongoing investigation.\n\nThe incident badly damaged Boeing's reputation and led to the MAX 9 being grounded for two weeks, a ban by the FAA on expanding production, a criminal investigation and the departure of several key executives. Boeing has vowed to make key quality improvements.\n\nBoeing's senior vice president for quality, Elizabeth Lund, and Doug Ackerman, vice president of supplier quality for Boeing, are among those who will testify during the hearings scheduled to last 20 hours over two days, the NTSB said.\n\nLund told the NTSB in a July 6 interview that the planemaker is building far fewer MAXs than it is allowed to produce. In June, it built in the \"low 20s and we are working our way back up. But at one point I think we were as low as eight.\"\n\nA flight attendant described a moment of terror when the door plug blew out. \"And then, just all of a sudden, there was just a really loud bang and lots of whooshing air, like the door burst open,\" the flight attendant said. \"Masks came down, I saw the galley curtain get sucked towards the cabin.\"\n\nTerry George, senior vice president and general manager for Boeing Program at Spirit AeroSystems, and Scott Grabon, a senior director for 737 quality at Spirit, which makes the fuselage for the MAX, will also appear, it added.\n\nLast month Boeing agreed to buy back Spirit AeroSystems, whose core plants it spun off in 2005, for $4.7 billion in stock.\n\nThe hearing will review issues including 737 manufacturing and inspections, safety management and quality management systems, FAA oversight, and issues surrounding the opening and closing of the door plug.\n\n'TOO HANDS OFF'\n\nBoeing has said no paperwork exists to document the removal of four key missing bolts. Lund said Boeing has now put a bright blue and yellow sign on the door plug when it arrives at the factory that says in big letters: \"Do not open\" and adds a redundancy \"to ensure that the plug is not inadvertently opened.\"\n\nIn June, FAA Administrator Mike Whitaker said the agency was \"too hands off\" in its oversight of Boeing before January. FAA employees told the NTSB that Boeing employees did not always followed required processes.\n\nJonathan Arnold, Aviation Safety Inspector at the FAA, said a systemic issue he witnessed at Boeing\u00b4s factory was employees not following the instructions.\n\n\"That seems to be systemic where they deviate from their instructions. And typically, tool control is what I see most,\" Arnold said.\n\nAlso in June, the NTSB said Boeing violated investigation rules when Lund provided non-public information to media and speculated about possible causes.\n\nLast month, Boeing agreed to plead guilty to a criminal fraud conspiracy charge and pay a fine of at least $243.6 million to resolve a Justice Department investigation into two 737 MAX fatal crashes.\n\n(Reporting by David Shepardson, Allison Lampert and Abhijith Ganapavaram; editing by Miral Fahmy and Nick Zieminski)", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType":
